{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} The '''Independent Payment Advisory Board''', or '''IPAB''', was to be a fifteen-member [[Federal government of the United States|United States Government]] [[Government agency|agency]] created in 2010 by sections 3403 and 10320 of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] which was to have the explicit task of achieving specified savings in Medicare without affecting coverage or quality. Under previous and current law, changes to Medicare payment rates and program rules are recommended by [[MedPAC]] but require an act of Congress to take effect. The system creating IPAB granted IPAB the authority to make changes to the Medicare program with the Congress being given the power to overrule the agency's decisions through supermajority vote. The [[Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018]] repealed IPAB before it could take effect.<ref>{{USPL|115|123}} sec. 52001.</ref>
Beginning in 2013, the Chief Actuary of the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] determined in particular years the projected per capita growth rate for Medicare for a multi-year period ending in the second year thereafter (the "implementation year"). If the projection exceeded a target growth rate, IPAB was to develop a proposal to reduce Medicare spending in the implementation year by a specified amount. If it was required to develop a proposal, the Board was to submit that proposal in January of the year before the implementation year; thus, the first proposal could have been submitted in January 2014 to take effect in 2015. If the Board failed to submit a proposal that the Chief Actuary certifies would achieve the savings target, the [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services|Secretary of Health and Human Services]] was to submit a proposal that would achieve that amount of savings. The Secretary was then to implement the proposal unless [[United States Congress|Congress]] enacted resolutions to override the Board's (or the Secretary's) decisions under a fast-track procedure that the law set forth.<ref name="AMA">[http://www.ama-assn.org/ama1/pub/upload/mm/399/hsr-payment-advisory-board.pdf Independent Payment Advisory Board] American Medical Association. "By Jan 1, 2015, and at least every other year thereafter, the IPAB will submit recommendations to slow the growth in national health care expenditures while preserving or enhancing quality of care."</ref>
A related group, the [[Specialty Society Relative Value Scale Update Committee]] (or Relative Value Update Committee; RUC), composed of [[physician]]s associated with the [[American Medical Association]], also advises the government about pay standards for Medicare patient procedures, according to news reports.<ref name="NYT-20150531">{{cite news |last=Pear |first=Robert |title=Federal Investigators Fault Medicare's Reliance on Doctors for Pay Standards |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/01/us/federal-investigators-fault-medicares-reliance-on-doctors-for-pay-standards.html |date=May 31, 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=June 1, 2015 }}</ref>
On February 9, 2018, the United States Congress voted to repeal the Independent Payment Advisory Board as a part of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018,<ref name= p610>"[https://www.appropriations.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Bipartisan%20Budget%20Act%20of%202018.pdf#page=610 Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018]". ''United States Senate''. February 7, 2018. p. 610.</ref> by a vote of 71−28 in the US Senate <ref>Carney, Jordain (February 9, 2018). "[http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/373092-senate-passes-bill-to-end-shutdown Senate passes bill to end shutdown, sending it to House]". ''The Hill''.</ref> and by a vote of 240−186 in US House of Representatives.<ref>"[http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2018/roll069.xml Final Vote Results for Roll Call 69]". ''United States House of Representatives''. February 9, 2018.</ref> Shortly thereafter that day, President Trump signed the budget bill into law,<ref>Kamisar, Ben; Zanona, Melanie; Marcos, Cristina (February 9, 2018). "[http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/373107-trump-signs-budget-deal-ending-shutdown Trump signs budget deal ending shutdown]". ''The Hill''.</ref> thereby repealing the IPAB.<ref name= p610/>
==Background== Congress created IPAB as a strengthened version of the [[Medicare Payment Advisory Commission]] (MedPAC), a body with no regulatory power that solely advises Congress, but cannot enact regulations in and of itself. Since 1997, MedPAC had recommended cuts totaling "hundreds of billions of dollars" to Medicare that were ignored by Congress.<ref name="Hill2">Mike Lillis. [http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/health-reform-implementation/111425-gop-leaders-push-to-repeal-medicare-cost-cutting-panel- “GOP leaders push to repeal Medicare cost-cutting panel.”] ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]''. (July 28, 2010).</ref> Congress has pressured Medicare administrators to cover "ineffective or needlessly costly methods of care," while Medicare's founding legislation says "Nothing in this title shall be construed to authorize any Federal officer or employee to exercise any supervision or control over the practice of medicine."<ref name="Aaron">{{Cite journal | author= [[Henry J. Aaron]] | title = The Independent Payment Advisory Board – Congress's 'Good Deed' | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] |date=May 2011 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMp1105144 | pmid = 21561342 |url=http://healthpolicyandreform.nejm.org/?p=14433 | volume=364 | issue=25 | pages=2377–9}}</ref> Henry Aaron, a health care expert at the [[Brookings Institution]], said that many observers saw that some in Congress are "in thrall to campaign contributors and producers and suppliers of medical services" and most are not well enough informed to wisely use Medicare's buying power to reform health care.<ref name="Aaron"/> The idea behind the IPAB was to take power away from Congress (and [[special interests]]<ref name="EconMan">{{cite news |title=Rockefeller: The Economists' Man in the Senate? |author=[[David Leonhardt]]|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 8, 2009 |url=https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/08/rockefeller-the-economists-man-in-the-senate/ |accessdate=July 5, 2011}}</ref>) in order to give it to those knowledgeable in health care policy.<ref name="Canwe">{{cite news|title=Can we control costs without Congress? |author=[[Ezra Klein]] |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 26, 2010 |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/ezra-klein/2010/03/can_we_control_costs_without_c.html |accessdate=June 18, 2011 |archivedate=June 18, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zXef5Wni?url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/ezra-klein/2010/03/can_we_control_costs_without_c.html |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Legislative history=== On June 25, 2009, Senator [[Jay Rockefeller]] introduced the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission Reform Act of 2009, which would have changed MedPAC into an executive branch agency.<ref>{{USBill|111|S.|1380}}</ref> On July 17, 2009, the Obama Administration submitted to Congress a similar proposal called the Independent Medicare Advisory Council Act, which would have created an independent five-member executive council to make recommendations to the president. From June 17 to September 14, 2009, three Democratic and three Republican [[United States Senate Committee on Finance|Senate Finance Committee]] members met for a series of thirty-one meetings to discuss the development of a health care reform bill. During this period, Senators [[Max Baucus]] (D-Montana), [[Chuck Grassley]] (R-Iowa), [[Kent Conrad]] (D-North Dakota), [[Olympia Snowe]] (R-Maine), [[Jeff Bingaman]] (D-New Mexico), and [[Mike Enzi]] (R-Wyoming), met for more than sixty hours, and their discussions established the principles upon which the health care reform legislation that later passed was based.<ref>{{cite web|title=Health Care Reform from Conception to Final Passage|accessdate=November 23, 2010|url=http://finance.senate.gov/issue/?id=32be19bd-491e-4192-812f-f65215c1ba65}}</ref> The Finance Committee included a provision establishing an independent Medicare advisory board in its health reform legislation,<ref>{{cite news |title=GOP Faces Choice If Health Bill Passes |author=Ronald Brownstein |newspaper=[[National Journal]] |date=November 13, 2009}}</ref> which passed the Senate on December 24, 2009.<ref name="Stockdale">Holly Stockdale. [http://assets.opencrs.com/rpts/R40915_20100126.pdf ''An Overview of Proposals to Establish an Independent Commission or Board in Medicare''.] Washington, D.C.: Congressional Research Service, 2010.</ref>
==Mission== IPAB was tasked with developing specific proposals to bring the net growth in Medicare spending back to target levels if the Medicare Actuary determines that net spending was forecast to exceed target levels, beginning in 2015.
With regard to IPAB's recommendations, the law said: "The proposal shall not include any recommendation to ration health care, raise revenues or Medicare beneficiary premiums under section 1818, 1818A, or 1839, increase Medicare beneficiary cost sharing (including deductibles, coinsurance, and co-payments), or otherwise restrict benefits or modify eligibility criteria."<ref>{{USStat|111|490}}; to be codified at {{USC|42|1899A(c)(2)(A)(ii).}}</ref> The [[Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS) was to implement these proposals unless Congress adopted equally effective alternatives. The board was also to be required to submit to Congress annual reports on [[health care prices in the United States|health care costs]], access, quality, and utilization. IPAB was to submit to Congress recommendations on how to slow the growth in total private health care expenditures.<ref name="Jost"/>
Every year, on September 1, IPAB was to submit a draft proposal to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. On January 15 of the next year, IPAB was to submit a proposal to Congress. If IPAB failed to meet this deadline, the HHS was to create its own proposal. Congress was to consider this proposal under special rules. Congress could not consider any amendment to the proposal that would not achieve similar cost reductions unless both houses of Congress, including a three-fifths super majority in the Senate, voted to waive this requirement. If Congress failed to adopt a substitute provision by August 15, HHS was to implement the proposal as originally submitted to Congress.<ref name="Jost"/>
==Membership and term of office== IPAB was to be composed of fifteen members appointed by the [[President of the United States|President]], subject to [[Advice and consent|Senate confirmation]]. The [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services|Secretary of Health and Human Services]], the Administrator of the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and the [[Health Resources and Services Administration|Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration]] were to serve ''[[ex officio]]'' as nonvoting members.<ref>{{USStat|111|502}}; to be codified at {{USC|42|1899A(g)(1)(A).}}</ref> In making the appointments, the President was to consult with the [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Majority Leader of the Senate]] concerning the appointment of three members; the [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]] concerning the appointment of three members, the [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Minority Leader of the Senate]] concerning the appointment of three members, and the [[Minority leader of the United States House of Representatives|Minority Leader of the House of Representatives]] concerning the appointment of three members.<ref>{{USStat|111|503}}; to be codified at {{USC|42|1899A(g)(1)(E).}}</ref>
The first members appointed to the Board were to be divided into three staggered classes in order to ensure that their terms would not expire simultaneously. Five were to be appointed for a term of one year, five were to be appointed for a term of three years, and five were to be appointed for a term of six years. All subsequent appointments were to be made for six years. A member was not to serve more than two full consecutive terms.<ref>{{USStat|111|503}}; to be codified at {{USC|42|1899A(g)(2).}}</ref>
Appointed members of the IPAB were to include individuals with national recognition for their expertise in health finance and economics, actuarial science, health facility management, health plans and integrated delivery systems, health facilities reimbursement, and other providers of health services or related fields to provide a mix of professionals, a broad geographic representation, and a balance between urban and rural areas. IPAB members were to include (but will not be limited to) physicians and other health professionals, experts in the area of pharmaco-economics or prescription drug benefit programs, employers, third-party payers, individuals skilled in the conduct and interpretation of biomedical, health services, and health economics research, and expertise in outcomes and effectiveness research and technology assessment. Members also were to include individuals representing consumers and the elderly. Individuals who were directly involved in providing or managing the delivery of Medicare items and services were not to constitute a majority of IPAB's membership.
The President of the United States was to [[executive order|establish a system]] for [[freedom of information|public disclosure]] by IPAB members of any financial and other potential conflicts of interest. No IPAB member was to be engaged in any other business, vocation or employment.<ref name=AMA/>
Members were to be paid at a rate described in Level III of the [[Executive Schedule]] that determines pay for senior executive branch officials. As of 2010, this was $165,300 a year.<ref name="Jost">{{Cite journal | author = Jost, Timothy Stoltzfus | title = The Independent Payment Advisory Board | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume = 363 | issue = 2 | pages = 103–105 |date=July 2010 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMp1005402 | pmid = 20505171 | url = http://healthpolicyandreform.nejm.org/?p=3478 }}</ref>
==Funding== Congress appropriated $15 million for IPAB in 2012. Future funding for the agency was to be based on this figure adjusted for inflation.<ref name="Jost"/>
==Reception==
===Predicted outcomes=== A 2009 ''[[Kaiser Health News]]'' article predicted [[primary care doctor]]s would likely see benefits from an "independent Medicare commission because the panel would be more likely to increase their fees and lower specialists' rates."<ref>{{cite news |title=Most health industry players would win under overhaul |author=Phil Galewitz |newspaper=[[Kaiser Health News]] |publisher=[[McClatchy Washington DC News Bureau]] |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2009/08/16/73802/most-health-industry-players-would.html |date=August 16, 2009 |accessdate=July 20, 2011}}</ref> While payment cuts to hospitals and hospices were to be off-limits until 2020, and clinical laboratories were to be off limits until 2016, physician fees could have been cut unless a [[doc fix]] to Medicare's sustainable growth rate formula made those cuts off limits.<ref name="Aaron"/> Other "savings would have to have been found in private [[Medicare Advantage]] plans, Medicare's Part D prescription-drug program, or spending on skilled-nursing facilities, home-based health care, [[dialysis]], durable medical equipment, ambulance services, and services of ambulatory surgical centers".<ref name="Aaron"/> According to the New England Journal of Medicine, holding off creation of [[accountable care organization]]s (ACOs) was likely to be a bad long term strategy for physicians.<ref>http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1011712</ref>
Critics of IPAB charged that the board's cost-cutting mandate would inevitably bring about a reduction in care, despite the anti-rationing language in the bill. Congressman [[Phil Roe (politician)|Phil Roe]] from Tennessee, a doctor, warned that IPAB would ration care through payment policy. [[American Medical News]] charged that the bill gave IPAB "unprecedented, dangerous authority to cut Medicare pay rates and strangle access to care."<ref>Fiegl, Charles, [http://www.amednews.com/article/20121015/government/310159952/4/ "Medicare IPAB: Rational or rationing?"], ''American Medical News'', October 15, 2012</ref>
===Experts=== {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} Health economist [[Uwe Reinhardt]] thought that given the "dubious style of [[Campaign finance in the United States|campaign financing]] of which we all are victims now," an independent Medicare commission was the U.S.'s only hope to restrain Medicare spending.<ref name="Helping">{{cite news |title=Helping Or Hurting Medicare? |author=Marilyn Werber Serafini |newspaper=[[National Journal]] |date=December 21, 2009 |url=http://healthcare.nationaljournal.com/2009/12/helping-or-hurting-medicare.php#1402314 |accessdate=July 31, 2011}}</ref> Reinhardt criticized former chairman of the [[United States House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health|House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health]] William Thomas' 1995 comment as emblematic of the spurious reasoning found in Congress. Of a payment system that resembled [[bundled payment]], Thomas said, "I'm not wild about a payment system that involves telling a bunch of innovative entrepreneurs that they can't be in the business anymore". Reinhardt criticized this, saying Thomas "seemed uninterested in what made more clinical and economic sense. His was purely an [[industrial policy]], not a health policy. And his reasoning explains why, year in year out, Congress has rejected economically sensible proposals to attain greater efficiency in the Medicare program."<ref name="Helping"/> Reinhardt compares the IPAB to a similar board in Germany, which he says is efficient, effective and civilized.<ref name="Brickbats">{{cite news |title=Medicare Payment Board Draws Brickbats |author=Julie Rovner |newspaper=[[Morning Edition]] |date=July 12, 2011 |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2011/07/12/137774959/medicare-payment-board-draws-brickbats |accessdate=July 31, 2011}}</ref>
====Former CBO directors==== [[Peter Orszag]], who directed the CBO and OMB in the Obama administration, said the IPAB may have been the most important aspect of the Affordable Care Act.<ref name="Motherjones">James Ridgeway. [http://motherjones.com/politics/2010/07/health-care-rationing-death-panels "Meet the Real Death Panels."] ''Mother Jones''. (July/August 2010).</ref> He said the board was "created to help address our long-term fiscal imbalance while boosting quality in health care".<ref>{{cite journal |author=[[Jon Meacham]] |date=May 10, 2010<!-- date associated with the volume and issue, not the internet article--> |title=In Search of a Fiscal Cure |journal=[[Newsweek]] |volume=155 |issue=19 |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2010/04/30/in-search-of-a-fiscal-cure.html }}</ref> "It's a very promising structure," said Orszag, but he cautioned that "whether it realizes its potential depends on how it's implemented."<ref name="Moving"/>
[[Douglas Holtz-Eakin]], a former CBO director and an economist who is currently president of [[American Action Network|a conservative political organization]], thought that despite "requirements that would force Congress to adopt the recommendations or find comparable savings," "cuts will be politically infeasible, as Congress is likely to continue regularly to override scheduled reductions."<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Holtz-Eakin D, Ramlet MJ |title=Analysis & commentary. Health care reform is likely to widen federal budget deficits, not reduce them |journal=[[Health Aff (Millwood)]] |volume=29 |issue=6 |pages=1136–41 |date=June 2010 |pmid=20530343 |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2010.0446}}</ref> In the words of [[Susan Dentzer]], editor of ''[[Health Affairs]]'', Holtz-Eakin thought no IPAB "will ever succeed in saving lawmakers from their own self-preserving instincts to pander."<ref>{{cite journal |author=Dentzer S |title=The risks and rewards of implementing health reform |journal=[[Health Aff (Millwood)]] |volume=29 |issue=6 |page=1092 |date=June 2010 |pmid=20530334 |doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2010.0518 |quote=But this inside the-trenches view conflicts with the more general impressions of the many doubters on the prospects for curve bending, including Douglas Holtz-Eakin and Michael J. Ramlet, who rightly invoke past instances when Congress squeezed the health system and later retrenched under political pressure. From their perspective, no Independent Payment Advisory Board would ever succeed in saving lawmakers from their own self-preserving instincts to pander.}}</ref>
===Politicians=== Sen. [[John Cornyn]], a Republican from Texas, introduced a bill in the Senate to prevent the creation of the IPAB.<ref name="Wrongway"/> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that Congressman and retired physician [[Phil Roe (politician)|Phil Roe]] (R-TN) twice sponsored House bills to eliminate the IPAB, which was partially why he was regarded as a "kindred soul" by the [[medical industry]].<ref name="Money">R. Jeffery Smith [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/06/AR2011020603109.html Health-related money continues to flow to members of Congress] ''The Washington Post''. February 6, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://roe.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=221489 Dr. Roe Introduces Legislation to Eliminate the Independent Payment Advisory Board: HR 452 – The Medicare Decisions Accountability Act] Press Release. January 26, 2011.</ref> Roe charged that IPAB would deny care. However, the legislation governing IPAB bared "any recommendation to ration health care."<ref name="Resurrect">{{cite news |title=It's Alive! GOPers Resurrect 'Death Panels' |author=Suzy Khimm |newspaper=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |date=January 27, 2011 |url=http://motherjones.com/politics/2011/01/gop-resurrects-death-panels |accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref>
[[Tom Daschle]], the former Senate Democratic leader who was Obama's first choice for health secretary, argued that IPAB should have been expanded to cover all forms of health insurance in order to prevent doctors from shifting costs onto patients with private medical insurance.<ref name="Moving">{{cite news |title=After Health Care Passage, Obama Pushes to Get It Rolling |author=Jackie Calmes |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 18, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/health/policy/18cost.html |accessdate=March 17, 2011}}</ref> After voting for the 2010 health care reform, [[Pete Stark]] (D-Calif.), said that the IPAB "sets [Medicare] up for unsustainable cuts" that will endanger the health of patients, and that he would "work tirelessly to mitigate the damage" the panel would cause.<ref name="Hill1">Julian Pecquet. [http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/politics-elections/124859-gop-staffer-look-to-healthcare-debate-for-repeal-clues “GOP staffer: Look to healthcare debate for repeal clues.”] ''The Hill''. (October 19, 2010).</ref>
===Lobbying groups=== The [[Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America]] said that elimination of the payment board was its top priority in the 2011 Congress.<ref name="Industry Aims"/> The [[American Hospital Association]] and the [[American Medical Association]] (AMA) have spoken out against the board.<ref name="Industry Aims">Duff Wilson [http://prescriptions.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/industry-targets-medicare-board/ "Industry Aims at Medicare Board"] ''The New York Times''. November 4, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Live Health Chat: Health care law changes |newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=February 17, 2011 }}</ref> The AMA wanted to change the IPAB requirement that members have no outside employment so working physicians could be considered.<ref>{{cite news |title=SPECIALTY DOCTORS TO VISIT CONGRESS JUNE 23 TO DISCUSS DOC FIX, IPAB, CODES |newspaper=Inside CMS|date=June 10, 2010}}</ref> The AMA also opposed any independent commission which could cut physician payment rates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ama-assn.org/ama1/pub/upload/mm/399/hsr-hr3590-ipab-provision-letter.pdf |title=Letter to the Honorable Harry Reid & Sen. Baucus, Harkin and Dodd; Rep. Pelosi, Hoyer, Miller, Rangel and Waxman |author=Michael D. Maves |publisher=American Medical Association |date=January 13, 2010 |accessdate=May 26, 2011}}</ref>
Dr. J. Fred Ralston Jr., president of the [[American College of Physicians]] (ACP), expressed support for the idea behind the IPAB, saying "making complex Medicare payment and budgetary decisions is very difficult within a political process with substantial lobbying pressures," but the group wanted to see significant changes. The ACP supported creating a position for a primary care physician on IPAB, additional protections to ensure that cost reductions would not lead to lower quality of care, authority for Congress to reject proposals made by IPAB via a simple majority vote, and equal treatment of all healthcare providers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Implementing Health Reform On the Independent Payment Advisory Board |newspaper=Internal Medicine News |date=August 1, 2010 |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |url=http://www.internalmedicinenews.com/views/implementing-health-reform/blog/the-independent-payment-advisory-board/f5efc423af.html}}</ref>
Dr. Elaine C. Jones, government relations committee cochair of the [[American Academy of Neurology]] stated, "We are also very concerned about the power of the IPAB to cut payments to physicians. The sole function of the IPAB is to cut spending with little guarantee of maintaining quality, access, and scientifically proven care. There may be no physician representation on the board either. These elements are concerning and unacceptable."<ref>{{cite news |title=Physicians Offer Rx for Fixing Health Reform Law |author=Mary Ellen Schneider |newspaper=Internal Medicine News|date=March 1, 2011 }}</ref>
Ron Pollack, the founding executive director of the health care advocacy group [[Families USA]], advised Democrats against being divided and conquered by supporting repeal of specific portions of the health care reform, such as IPAB.<ref name="Dems prepare defense">Julian Pecquet [http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/health-reform-implementation/134441-with-repeal-threat-looming-democrats-set-to-defend-healthcare-law Dems prepare defense of healthcare law in face of repeal threats] ''The Hill''. December 21, 2010.</ref>
Two major nursing home associations, the [[American Health Care Association]] and the American Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, along with seventy two other healthcare groups, urged Congress to reject IPAB. They argued that the board would have had too much control over Medicare and would affect the ability of healthcare providers to lobby for changes in how they are reimbursed. The groups also argued that IPAB would have only been accountable to the president.<ref>{{cite news |title=Providers try to quash Medicare payment board proposal |newspaper=McKnights Long Term Care News and McKnights Assisted Living |date=January 13, 2010 }}</ref>
The [[American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons]] made IPAB a focus of their advocacy work. Hospital exemptions from 2015 to 2020 as well as the lack of practicing physicians on the board itself were major concerns. Lobbying efforts in April 2011 focused on making these modifications if not fully eliminating the board.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
Medical specialty groups spearheaded efforts to repeal IPAB. The [[American Society of Anesthesiologists]] and [[American Association of Neurological Surgeons]] co-lead a coalition of 26 medical specialties and patient organizations representing more than 350,000 physicians and their patients dedicated to repealing IPAB.<ref>http://www.asahq.org/For-Members/Advocacy/Washington-Alerts/IPAB-Repeal-Coalition-endorses-the-Protecting-Seniors-Access-to-Medicare-Act-of-2013.aspx</ref><ref>http://politi.co/XVzKV9</ref> The coalition endorsed efforts in the [[113th Congress]] to repeal IPAB.<ref>http://www.asahq.org/For-Members/Advocacy/Washington-Alerts/~/media/For%20Members/Advocacy/IPAB/Protecting%20Seniors%20Access%20to%20Medicare%20Act%20Endorsement11813.ashx</ref>
[[Howard Dean]], a consultant for [[Washington, D.C.]]-based [[lobbying firm]] [[McKenna, Long and Aldridge]] and former [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[Governor of Vermont]], believed the IPAB would fail to control costs and should be abolished. He opposed the premise of the board, writing in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' that it was "a health-care rationing body" and that "rate setting—the essential mechanism of the IPAB—has a 40-year track record of failure."<ref>[[Howard Dean|Dean, Howard]] (July 28, 2013). "[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324110404578628542498014414 The Affordable Care Act's Rate-Setting Won't Work]". ''The Wall Street Journal''.</ref>
===Editorials=== In an editorial opposing Sen. Cornyn's bill to repeal IPAB ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote, "The political system failed when it came to controlling health-care costs. The 15-member panel that Mr. Cornyn et al. deride as 'beltway bureaucrats' would be a group of experts in the field, nominated by the president, chosen in part by congressional leaders of the opposing party and subject to Senate confirmation. Congress isn't bound by its proposals if lawmakers can come up with what they think is a better approach. Getting costs under control is going to require difficult choices – including, in the case of Medicare, difficult political choices. This unwise bill is not a good sign about Washington's willingness to make them."<ref name="Wrongway">{{cite news |title=Wrong way on health care; A Republican proposal to eliminate a cost control board is a bad prescription. |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=August 16, 2010 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/15/AR2010081502470.html |accessdate=March 17, 2011}}</ref>
===Death panel controversy=== The term "[[death panel]]" was used in conjunction with IPAB.<ref>Roy, Avik, [http://www.nationalreview.com/agenda/256127/epistemology-death-panels-avik-roy The Epistemology of Death Panels], ''National Review'', December 31, 2010.</ref> Sarah Palin wrote in the ''Wall Street Journal'' that the [[National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform]] "implicitly endorses the use of "death panel"-like rationing by way of the new Independent Payments [sic] Advisory Board."<ref>Palin, Sarah, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703766704576009322838245628 Why I Support the Ryan Roadmap], ''Wall Street Journal'', December 10, 2010.</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported some Obama administration officials feared the Independent Payment Advisory Board could be "target for attacks of the 'death panel' sort";<ref>{{cite news |title=After Health Care Passage, Obama Pushes to Get It Rolling |author=Jackie Calmes |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 17, 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/health/policy/18cost.html |accessdate=}}</ref> An October 2010 [[National Right to Life Committee|National Right to Life]] article wrote the IPAB was "a good candidate for the title of 'death panel,'"<ref>{{cite journal |author=Burke J. Balch | date=October 2010 |title=Are ObamaCare "Death Panels" Truly a Myth? |journal=National Right to Life News |publisher=[[National Right to Life Committee]] |volume=37 |issue=10 |pages=10, 18 |url=http://www.nrlc.org/news_and_views/Oct10/nv100110part2.html}}</ref> and a December 2010 ''Wall Street Journal'' editorial associated 'death panels' with the IPAB.<ref>Rivkin, David and Foley, Elizabeth Price, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203513204576047742746513406 'Death Panels' Come Back to Life], ''Wall Street Journal'', December 30, 2010</ref>
Former OMB Director Orszag responded: "I think it's only in Washington, D.C., that a board created to help address our long-term fiscal imbalance while boosting quality in health care and that is specifically by law prohibited from rationing care could be called a death panel".<ref>{{cite journal |author=[[Jon Meacham]] |date=May 10, 2010<!-- date associated with the volume and issue, not the internet article--> |title=In Search of a Fiscal Cure |journal=[[Newsweek]] |volume=155 |issue=19 |pages= |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2010/04/30/in-search-of-a-fiscal-cure.html }}</ref>
==Congressional Budget Office scoring== The [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) estimated{{When|date=July 2011}} that IPAB would achieve Medicare spending reductions of $28 billion through 2019—amounting to 0.4 percent of the projected Medicare spending of ~$7 trillion for the period.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = [[Alain C. Enthoven]] | title = Reforming Medicare by reforming incentives | journal = [[The New England Journal of Medicine]] | volume = 364 | issue = 21 | pages = e44 |date=May 2011 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMp1104427 | pmid = 21561341 | url = http://healthpolicyandreform.nejm.org/?p=14437}}</ref>
In March 2011, the CBO estimated the Medicare baseline level of spending would not exceed targets throughout the years of 2015 to 2021; thus, the IPAB was not expected to affect any Medicare spending.<ref>[http://www.cbo.gov/budget/factsheets/2011b/medicare.pdf March 2011 Medicare baseline] CBO. p. 2. Retrieved October 27, 2011.</ref>
==Fiscal commission report== The 2010 presidential commission, the [[National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform]], issued a report on reducing the federal deficit and voted 11 to 7 to strengthen the IPAB. It wished to bring forward the time by which health care providers would be affected by IPAB decisions.<ref name="hill2">Erik Wasson. [http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/health-reform-implementation/131635-ryan-says-debt-plan-would-entrench-obamacare- “Rep. Ryan says deficit reduction plan would ‘entrench ObamaCare’”] ''The Hill''. (December 2, 2010).</ref><ref>The National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform. [http://www.fiscalcommission.gov/sites/fiscalcommission.gov/files/documents/TheMomentofTruth12_1_2010.pdf ''The Moment of Truth''], at 41. Dec. 2010.</ref><ref name="atlantic1">Derek Thompson, [https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2010/12/the-plan-to-balance-the-budget-the-fiscal-commissions-final-report/67272/, "The Plan to Balance the Budget: The Fiscal Commission's Final Report."] ''[[The Atlantic]]''. (December 1, 2010).</ref><ref name="post1">Ezra Klein. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/03/AR2010120306669.html “The best and worst of Simpson-Bowles.”] ''[[The Washington Post]]''. (December 3, 2010).</ref> The recommendations "would hit hospitals the hardest, which gained an exemption from the group's decisions for several years."<ref name="nationaljournal1">Mathew DoBias. [http://nationaljournal.com/domesticpolicy/deficit-panel-offers-partial-answer-on-health-care-20101201 “Deficit Panel Offers Partial Answer on Health Care.”] ''[[National Journal]]''. (December 1, 2010).</ref>
==Lawsuit== {{main | Coons v. Geithner}} As part of legal challenges from conservative organizations and state attorneys general in about twenty states to the Affordable Care Act, Arizona's conservative [[Goldwater Institute]], along with three Republican congressman from Arizona, filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the IPAB.<ref name="Ariz Congressmen">{{cite news |title=Ariz. congressmen join health reform lawsuit |author=Elise Viebeck |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/healthwatch/health-reform-implementation/114165-ariz-congressmen-join-health-reform-lawsuit- |newspaper=The Hill |date=August 13, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}</ref> ''The Hill'' reported that "while the suit illustrates conservative frustration with the federal government, the courts rarely strike down advisory boards created by Congress."<ref name="Ariz Congressmen"/> The suit was dismissed in 2012. The Ninth Circuit found for the government on appeal, and the Supreme Court declined to hear a further appeal.<ref>https://www.politico.com/story/2015/03/supreme-court-obamacare-case-decline-medical-board-116504</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = The Lord Laidlaw | image = Irvine Laidlaw.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Irvine Laidlaw | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1942|12|22}} | birth_place = [[Keith, Scotland|Keith]], Banffshire | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Monaco]]
London
[[Noordhoek, Cape Town]] | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = [[Institute for International Research]] | education = [[Merchiston Castle School]] | alma_mater = [[Leeds University]]
[[Columbia Business School]] | employer = | occupation = Businessman | home_town = | title = Baron Laidlaw of Rothiemay | salary = | networth = £795 million (2017) | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] | boards = | religion = | spouse = Christine | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Irvine Alan Stewart Laidlaw, Baron Laidlaw''' (born 12 December 1942 in [[Keith, Scotland|Keith, Banffshire, Scotland]]) is a British businessman, and a former member of the [[House of Lords]]. In the ''[[Sunday Times Rich List 2012]]'' ranking of the wealthiest people in the UK he was placed 105th with an estimated fortune of £745 million.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/richlist ''Sunday Times Rich List 2012'' online edition] ==Biography== The son of a [[Banffshire]] mill-owner, Laidlaw was educated at [[Merchiston Castle School]], [[Leeds University]] and New York City's [[Columbia Business School]].{{citenews|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article3822710.ece|title=Tory peer Lord Laidlaw seeks treatment for sex addiction|publisher=The Sunday Times|date=27 April 2008|accessdate=27 April 2008}} Laidlaw, a former member of the House of Lords, also donated $2 million to Columbia Business School for scholarships and increased opportunities for Business students.{{cite web|title=Lord Laidlaw donates $2 million for scholarships|url=http://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/newsroom/newsn/3467}} Irvine Laidlaw founded The Laidlaw Undergraduate Internship Programme in research and Leadership at the [[University of St Andrews]], after donating to the cause. He is also an honorary graduate at the university. As well as the being the founder, Laidlaw is a trustee of The Laidlaw Schools Trust (LST), which was approved by the [[Department for Education|DfE]] as a multi-academy sponsor. It was established on 24 May 2012.{{cite web|title=The Laidlaw Schools Trust approved by the DfE as a multi academy sponsor|url=http://www.laidlawschoolstrust.com/}} After graduation, Laidlaw turned a small US publishing company bought in 1973 into the [[Institute for International Research]] (IIR), the world's largest conference organiser. After calling off a £500m flotation in 2001 when the market plunged, he sold in 2005 for a sum believed to be in the order of £768m. Laidlaw previously owned and raced a [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]], which won [[24 Hours of Le Mans|Le Mans]] a number of times throughout the 1950s, along with a number of other vintage cars, including a [[Ferrari 250 GTO|1962 Ferrari GTO]]. in 2013, Irvine Laidlaw stopped racing.{{cite web|title=Wind farm clinches biggest renewable financing|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-01/racing-baron-s-wind-farm-clinches-biggest-renewable-financing|publisher=Bloomberg}} He recently sold a collection of classic sports cars to raise £17 million.{{cite web|title=Irvine Laidlaw poised to raise £17m by selling off his collection of classic sports cars|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/lord-irvine-laidlaw-expected-bring-2064604|publisher=Daily Record}} In 1988 Laidlaw founded Abbey Business Centres, a subsidiary of IIR providing serviced office space, meeting room facilities and virtual office packages in 13 business centres in Great Britain.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2916668/Informa-beats-rivals-to-buy-Laidlaws-firm-for-1.4billion.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Harry | last=Wallop | title=Informa beats rivals to buy Laidlaw's firm for .4billion | date=2 June 2005}} The first business centre opened in [[Glasgow]], and soon the company opened up another centre in [[Slough]], Berkshire. Other centres were added, and in 2009 a total of 13 centres made up the organisation. In 2015, the University of Leeds launched an official opening for the £26 million Laidlaw Library, named after Irvine Laidlaw, who had previously studied economics at the University in the 1960s. His £9 million donation is the largest the university has received from any donor.{{cite web|title=New state-of-the-art Leeds library|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/latest-news/top-stories/lord-melvyn-bragg-opens-new-state-of-the-art-leeds-library-1-7349712|publisher=Yorkshire Evening Post}} Laidlaw part owns a $2.1 billion wind-farm project, and earlier this year secured the largest clean-energy financing in 2015 from eight lenders, which included Deutsche Bank AG.{{cite web|title=Wind farm clinches biggest renewable financing|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-07-01/racing-baron-s-wind-farm-clinches-biggest-renewable-financing|publisher=Bloomberg}} ==Conservative Party donations== One of the largest financial backers of the UK's [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], Laidlaw was made a [[life peer]] as '''Baron Laidlaw''', of [[Rothiemay]] in Banffshire on 14 June 2004.{{London Gazette |issue=57328 |date=17 June 2004 |page=7561}} According to the records of the [[UK Electoral Commission]], on 27 November 2007, Laidlaw gave a donation of £2,990,532.20 to the Conservatives.{{citenews|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/feb/21/partyfunding|title=Party donations hit midterm record of £56m|publisher=The Guardian|date=21 February 2008|accessdate=27 April 2008}} Laidlaw donated £25,000 to the 2008 [[London Mayor]]al election campaign of [[Boris Johnson]]. ==Tax status== In 2008, Lord Laidlaw was described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as a "Monaco-based [[tax exile]]".{{cite news | first=Jamie | last=Doward | author2= | title= How short-selling profited the Tories A group of high-profile hedge fund managers who have been criticised for exacerbating the financial crisis are part of an elite pack of Conservative supporters, reports Jamie Doward. Could David Cameron's commitment to transforming the party image fall victim to the credit crunch? | date=28 September 2008 | publisher= | url =https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/sep/28/marketturmoil.shares | work =[[The Guardian]] | pages = | accessdate = 28 September 2008 | language = | location=London}} Lord Laidlaw was criticised in April 2007 in the press for failing to become UK tax resident despite being appointed to the House of Lords. The [[BBC]] said that, in a letter seen by them, Laidlaw "cites a variety of personal reasons" for non-compliance.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article3056699.ece Row over Tories’ offshore donor, Irvine Laidlaw] Sunday Times – 16 December 2007 Criticism by [[Dennis Stevenson, Baron Stevenson of Coddenham]], chair of the [[House of Lords Appointments Commission]], on assurances given to the Commission by Laidlaw to become a UK tax resident by April 2004, were followed by Laidlaw taking leave of absence from the House of Lords.{{citenews|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/jun/07/partyfunding.uk|title=Tory donor criticised over tax status|publisher=The Guardian|date=7 June 2007|accessdate=27 April 2008}} In 2010 following the enactment of the [[Constitutional Reform and Governance Act 2010]] he stepped down from his seat in the House of Lords to maintain his non-domiciled status and so be able to avoid paying UK residents' taxes. ==Charity donations== In 2004, Laidlaw said that he would over the next 20–30 years donate most of his fortune to helping disadvantaged young people. His main vehicle was the Laidlaw Youth Project, which supported a range of charitable work for disadvantaged youngsters in Scotland from 2004 to 2007 when it became the Laidlaw Youth Trust. He has also donated:{{citenews|url=http://news.scotsman.com/laidlawscharitydonations/Tycoon-Laidlaw-to-give-away.2830133.jp|title=Tycoon Laidlaw to give away fortune|publisher=The Scotsman|date=26 November 2006|accessdate=27 April 2008}} * £2 million to [[The Prince's Trust]]{{citenews|url=http://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/mediacentre/inthenews/prince_s_trust_donation_253381602.html|title=Prince's Trust donation|publisher=The Prince's Trust|date=28 June 2006|accessdate=27 April 2008}} * After [[Moray]] Council earmarked Rothiemay Primary School for closure, Laidlaw donated funds to a parents campaign which successfully kept 21 schools open * Donated R9 million to fund the Amakhaya Ngoku housing project{{cite web|title=Lord Laidlaw donating R9 million to fund Amakhaya Ngoku housing project|url=http://uctscholar.uct.ac.za/PDF/57852_Tyler,%20R.pdf|publisher=University of Cape Town|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007024711/http://uctscholar.uct.ac.za/PDF/57852_Tyler,%20R.pdf|archivedate=7 October 2015|df=dmy-all}} * Laidlaw scholarship at Newcastle University, in which he funds 50% of the funding along with the university. * Supporting the Glyndebourne Festival production.{{cite web|title=Glyndebourne Festival season preview|url=http://www.glyndebourne.com/discover/news-and-blogs/2013/august/1934-2014-80th-anniversary-glyndebourne-festival-season-preview/|publisher=Glyndebourne}} * Donating £100,000 to Scottish Opera{{cite web|title=Lord Laidlaw donates to Scottish Opera|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12434924.A_night_at_the_opera__thanks_to_a_generous_millionaire_Lord_Laidlaw_donates_GBP100_000_to_company/|publisher=Scotland Herald}} * Private investor for Ben Ainslie Racing{{cite web|title=Ainslie Announces Cup Team|url=http://www.yachtingworld.com/blogs/matthew-sheahan/ainslie-announces-cup-team-162|publisher=Yachting World}} * Donor to the Rural Education Access Programme{{cite web|title=Rural Education Access Programme|url=http://www.reap.org.za/pieces/reports/pdf/progress_reports/mid_year/2010_REAP_mid_year_progress_report.pdf}} * £40,000 to Keith Grammar School, to fund a scheme to help senior pupils prepare for the world of work * £1 million to [[Merchiston Castle School]] his former school; despite having disliked attending it, he eventually relented to persuasion by the headmaster and donated this sum. The new sixth-form house at the school, which his donation went some way to financing is named Laidlaw House. * £9 million to the [[University of Leeds]] to support the development of the new undergraduate library, the Laidlaw Library, which opened in May 2015.{{cite web|title=About the Laidlaw Library|url=https://library.leeds.ac.uk/info/416/building_developments/288/about_the_laidlaw_library/1|website=University Library|publisher=University of Leeds|accessdate=23 July 2015}} In 2007, he set up the Laidlaw Youth Trust which from 2007 to 2009 spent over £6 million in Scotland on good causes related to disadvantaged children and young people. In 2007, in emerged that the [[Scottish Executive]] had given sufficient donations to pay the salary of the CEO Laidlaw Youth project, Maureen McGinn – who is also the wife of Scotland's most senior civil servant, [[John Elvidge|Sir John Elvidge]].{{citenews|url=http://www.sundayherald.com/news/heraldnews/display.var.1411844.0.executive_funded_tory_tax_exiles_charity_with_taxpayers_money.php|title=Executive funded Tory tax exile's charity with taxpayers' money|publisher=Sunday Herald|date=20 May 2007|accessdate=27 April 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528192155/http://www.sundayherald.com/news/heraldnews/display.var.1411844.0.executive_funded_tory_tax_exiles_charity_with_taxpayers_money.php|archivedate=28 May 2007|df=dmy-all}} In 2008, Laidlaw became a sponsor to Excelsior Academy in Newcastle's West End. He donated £30,000,000 towards the construction of the school. He closed the Trust in 2009 because he was spending more time in South Africa and said he wanted to focus his charitable giving there. It is not known how much he has gifted in his new adopted country but he was involved in some township housing project. In 2014, an undergraduate internship scheme was set up at the [[University of St. Andrews]] through a donation from Lord Laidlaw who is an honorary graduate of the University.{http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/students/involve/laidlaw/ | The Laidlaw Undergraduate Internship Programme in Research and Leadership} ==Personal life== Laidlaw and his wife Christine divide their time between an apartment in [[Monaco]] overlooking the harbour; and their South African home, an early 20th-century 23,200 m2 estate in [[Noordhoek, Cape Town|Noordhoek]], near Cape Town. At the time of the purchase, in November 2005, it was the country's most expensive property, bought for R106 million. ===Hobbies=== Laidlaw regularly competes in historic car racing around the world with his [[Porsche 904]]GTS, Porsche 904/6, [[Maserati]] 250S & Maserati 6CM. Laidlaw also won a medal in the Scottish amateur rally, using a Ford Focus ST. In 2007 Laidlaw added a 1001 hp [[Bugatti Veyron]] to his extensive car collection, which is sometimes seen between Noordhoek and Cape Town, on the world-famous coastal road [[Chapman's Peak Drive]]. Laidlaw has won the [[Key West]] [[Regatta]] twice using his Swan 60 cruiser-racer, ''[[Highland Fling]]''. He began a voyage around the world in Oceanco built motor yacht, the ''Lady Christine'', in 2003. Highland Fling XI won the Round the Island Race 2017.{{url=http://www.roundtheisland.org.uk/web/code/php/main_c.php?section=race|title=Round The Island Race results}} ===Sex life allegations=== In April 2008, Laidlaw was the target of a sting operation staged by investigative journalist [[Mazher Mahmood]] on behalf of the British tabloid ''[[The News of the World]],'' which revealed that Laidlaw hires up to five £3,000 [[Prostitute|vice girls]] at a time for all-night [[orgies]] involving [[spanking]], [[bondage (BDSM)|bondage]] and [[lesbian]] sex at his Monaco home. After submitting a written confession to the newspaper in which he allegedly confesses a lifetime fighting [[sex addiction]],{{cite web|url=http://www.newsoftheworld.co.uk/2704_lord_laidlaws_letter.shtml|title=Lord Laidlaw's letter of confession|publisher=The News of the World|date=April 27, 2008|accessdate=2008-04-27}} Laidlaw has reportedly checked himself into a six-week residential sex addict programme in South Africa, and donated £1 million to help fellow sufferers.{{citenews|url=http://www.newsoftheworld.co.uk/2704_baron_hard_up.shtml|title=Top Tory Lord Laidlaw's sex games with 4 girls, one gigolo and a tri-lingual bisexual|publisher=The News of the World|date=April 27, 2008|accessdate=2008-04-27}} ==Arms== {{Infobox COA wide |image = |image size = |notes = |year_adopted = |coronet = [[Coronet|Coronet of a Baron]] |escutcheon = Sable, a Chevron Or, between in chief two Bezants, and in base a Sheep statant Argent. |supporters = Dexter: a Boy wearing a Kilt of Scot Green Tartan proper.
Sinister: a Girl wearing a Dress Argent, and Sash of Scot Green Tartan proper. |crest = A Red Squirrel sejant proper. |badge = |motto = '''SEMPER CONTENDO''' ''(Always disputing)'' |symbolism = }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.superyachttimes.com/yachts/details/572/ Superyacht ''Lady Christine'' at Superyacht Times] *[https://www.theyworkforyou.com/peer/lord_laidlaw Lord Laidlaw] at [[TheyWorkForYou]] *[http://www.abbeyoffices.com Abbey Business Centres] *[https://library.leeds.ac.uk/new-undergraduate-library The Laidlaw Library] at the [[University of Leeds]]. {{DEFAULTSORT:Laidlaw, Irvine}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Merchiston Castle School]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Leeds]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) life peers]] [[Category:Scottish Conservative Party politicians]] [[Category:Scottish billionaires]] [[Category:People from Keith, Moray]] [[Category:British car collectors]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) donors]] [[Category:Scottish expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:British expatriates in Monaco]]

The '''Kameido incident''' took place in 1923 in the aftermath of the [[1923 Great Kantō earthquake|Great Kantō earthquake]].
==Background== On September 1, 1923, the Great Kantō earthquake struck [[Tokyo]] and [[Yokohama]] and martial law was imposed in the aftermath of the earthquake.<ref>{{cite book | title= Columbia Chronologies of Asian History and Culture |publisher= Columbia University Press |author= John Bowman |year= Jan 22, 2005|pages= 151 | isbn=}}</ref> On the evening of September 3, the Kameido police in Tokyo began arresting known social activists, suspecting that they would "spread disorder or forment revolution amid the confusion". During the mass arrests, police arrested union leader Hirasawa Keishichi, and Nakatsuji Uhachi, a member of the Pure Laborers' Union. The [[Special Higher Police]] arrest seven members of the Nankatsu Labor Association. Army troops detained an eighth member of the association, Sato Kinji.<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref>
Between late at night on September 3 and September 5, troops of the 13th Cavalry Regiment on emergency duty in Kameido shot and decapitated Hirasawa and nine others. They disposed of the bodies, together with those of [[Korean people|Korean]] and [[Chinese people|Chinese]] massacre victims, along the banks of the Arakawa drainage canal. The police issued an official notice on October 14, claiming that troops had shot the men because they were agitating prisoners. The following year, the Liberal Lawyers' Association and union leaders worked to bring the facts to light and establish responsibility, with partial success. Police claimed to have cremated the remains of the victims. With no remains to bury, a memorial service was held in February 1924.<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref>
==Victims of the Kameido Incident== *Hirasawa Keishichi<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Kawai Yoshitora<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Kato Koju<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *KItashima Kichizo<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Kondo Kozo<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Nakatsuji Uhachi<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Sato Kinji<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Suzuki Naoichi<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Yamagishi Jitsuji<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref> *Yoshimura Koji<ref>{{cite book | title= Labor and Imperial Democracy in Prewar Japan |publisher= University of California Press |author= Andrew Gordon |year= Jan 21, 1991|pages= | isbn=}}</ref>

This is a '''list of bordering countries with the greatest relative differences in GDP (PPP) per person'''; specifically those pairs of neighbouring countries where the richer country is at least twice as wealthy on a per capita basis than the poorer. These statistics however do not consider differences in other economic indicators that measure welfare, such as their [[human development index]], or inequality within countries. == Characteristics == The greatest cases of inequity typically would involve an impoverished and politically unstable country neighbouring a resource-rich and relatively stable one, although neither may be recognised as a [[high-income economy]]. As an extreme example, the GDP per capita for [[Saudi Arabia]], is over 42 times greater to that of its neighbour [[Yemen]]. In the four biggest ratios, the poorer country is either [[Yemen]] or [[North Korea]]. Due to lack of economic data, the [[Vatican City]] (which is surrounded by [[Italy]]), [[Collectivity of Saint Martin|Saint Martin]] (which shares the island of [[Saint Martin]] with [[Sint Maarten]]) and the [[British Overseas Territory|British Overseas Territories]] of [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia]] located in the island of [[Cyprus]], are not included in this list. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: right" |- ! page.title: List of royal saints and martyrs

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=October 2015}} {{refimprove|date=December 2012}} }}
This '''list of royal saints and martyrs''' enumerates [[Christianity|Christian]] [[monarchs]], [[Royal family|other royalty]], and [[nobility]] who have been [[beatification|beatified]] or [[canonization|canonized]], or who are otherwise venerated as or conventionally given the appellation of "[[saint]]" or "[[Christian martyrs|martyr]]". Their names are in English and, where known, in their own language. When the status of a nominee is dubious the whole entry is ''italicized''.
==Monarchs==
This section enumerates [[Christian]] sovereigns, as opposed to mere [[spouse|consort]]s, who are enumerated in "Other royalty and nobility" below.
===Saints===
[[File:Abgarwithimageofedessa10thcentury.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Abgar V of Edessa]], the first Christian monarch in history, holding the [[Image of Edessa]]]] [[File:StefanIHongarije.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|[[Stephen I of Hungary|St. Stephen I, King of Hungary]]]] [[File:Louis-ix.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Louis IX of France|St. Louis IX, King of France]]]] *'''[[Abgarus of Edessa]]''', King of [[Osroene]]<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01042c.htm Leclercq, Henri. "The Legend of Abgar." ''The Catholic Encyclopedia''. Vol. 1. New York, New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 19 February 2013.]</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Aethelberht of Kent]]''' (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Aethelberht II of East Anglia]]''' (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Alexander Nevsky]]'''<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/67400 "Sant' Alessandro Nevskij"]</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Alfred the Great|Alfred the Great of Wessex]]''', died 26 October 899 (Anglican) *'''[[Amadeus IX, Duke of Savoy]]''' (Catholic) *'''[[Andrey Bogolyubsky]]''', first [[Grand Prince of Vladimir]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Archil of Kakheti]]''', martyr<ref>Machitadze, Archpriest Zakaria. 2007. [http://www.pravoslavie.ru/enarticles/070704163300 "Holy Royal Martyrs Archil and Luarsab"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517145656/http://www.pravoslavie.ru/enarticles/070704163300 |date=17 May 2008 }}. ''The Lives of the Georgian Saints''. ''Pravoslavie.Ru''. Accessed on 11 November 2007.</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Ashot I of Iberia]]''', martyr (Orthodox) *'''[[Boris I of Bulgaria]]'''<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/92251 "San Boris Michele I"]</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Canute IV of Denmark]]''', in [[Danish language|Danish]] "''Knud 4. den Hellige''"<ref>[http://www.ewtn.com/saintsHoly/saints/C/stcanuteiv.asp "St. Canute IV".]</ref> (Catholic) *'''[[Charles I of England]]''', martyr, died 30 January 1649 (Anglican) *'''[[Charles I, Count of Flanders]]''', known as "St. Charles the Good", in French "''Charles le Bon''", in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] "''Karel de Goede''" (Catholic) *'''[[Constantin Brancoveanu]]''', King of Wallachia<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/92431]</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Constantine of Cornwall|Constantine]]''', King of [[Dumnonia]], martyr<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/44500]</ref> (there is confusion regarding his identity) *'''[[Constantine I]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 337, known as "Constantine the Great" and "Constantine, Equal-to-the-Apostles" ("''Κωνσταντίνος Α' Ἰσαπόστολος''") (Byzantine Catholic, Lutheran, and Orthodox) *'''[[Constantine IV]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 685, known as "Constantine the New"<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/92483]</ref><ref>http://www.byzantium.xronikon.com/bitsaint.html</ref> (Orthodox) *'''''[[Constantine XI]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 1453, known as "Constantine XI Palaiologos", "The [[Marble Emperor]]", "The Last Roman Emperor"; not officially recognized by either the Byzantine Catholic or Orthodox churches, he is popularly regarded in both as the national patron saint, i. e., "Ethnomartyr" ("''Ἐθνομάρτυρας''"), meaning "national martyr" (unofficial)'' *'''[[Cormac mac Cuilennáin]]''', [[Kingdom of Munster|King of Munster]] (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Dagobert II]]''', martyr, [[Merovingian]] [[king of Austrasia]], son of St. Sigebert III (Catholic) *'''[[David I of Scotland]]''', son of [[St. Margaret of Scotland]] (see under "Other royalty and nobility" below), in [[Gaelic language|Gaelic]] "''Naomh Daibhidh''" {{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} (Catholic) *'''[[David IV of Georgia]]''', known as "David the Builder" (Orthodox) *'''[[David of Trebizond]]'''<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.omhksea.org/2013/08/canonization-of-new-saints-by-the-ecumenical-patriarchate/ | title = Canonization of New Saints by the Ecumenical Patriarchate | date = 2 August 2013 | publisher = Ecumenical Patriarchate - Orthodox Metropolitanate of Hong Kong and South East Asia | accessdate = 1 November 2018}}</ref> (Orthodox) *'''[[Demetre I of Georgia]]''' (Orthodox) *'''[[Demetre II of Georgia]]''', martyr, known as "Demetre the Self-Sacrificer" (Orthodox) *'''[[Eberhard of Friuli|Eberhard]], Duke of Friuli''', son-in-law of Frankish emperor [[Louis the Pious]] and ancestor of all contemporary royals (Catholic) *'''[[Edmund the Martyr]]''', [[Kingdom of East Anglia|King of East Anglia]] (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Edward the Confessor]]''', [[Kingdom of England|King of England]] (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Edward the Martyr]]''', [[Kingdom of England|King of England]] (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Edwin of Northumbria]]''' (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''''[[Eric IX of Sweden]]''', martyr, died 18 May 1161, [[Pope Alexander III]] forbid his ''[[Cult (religious practice)|cultus]]'' in 1172, and he was never canonized, but he is revered as a patron saint of [[Sweden]],<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14297a.htm]</ref><ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/15207a.htm]</ref> in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] "''Erik den helige''" and "''S:t Erik''" (unofficial)'' *'''[[Fedelmid mac Crimthainn]]''', [[Kingdom of Munster|King of Munster]] (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Ferdinand III of Castile]]''', known as "Ferdinand III the Saint", in Spanish "''San Fernando''" and "''Fernando III el Santo''" (Catholic) *'''[[Guntram]]''', [[Merovingian]] king of [[Burgundy]] (Catholic) *'''[[Henry II, Holy Roman Emperor]]''', husband of [[Cunigunde of Luxemburg]] (see under "Other royalty and nobility" below), known as "St. Henry II", in [[German language|German]] "''Heinrich II. der Heilige''" ("Henry II the Holy") (Catholic) *'''[[Hermenegild|Hermenegild of the Visigoths]]''' (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Humbert III of Savoy]]''' (Catholic) *'''[[Jadwiga of Poland]]''', known as "St. Hedwig of Poland" and "St. Hedwig, Queen of Poland", in [[Polish language|Polish]] "''Św. Jadwiga Królowa Polski''" (Catholic) *'''[[John III Doukas Vatatzes|John III]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 1254, known as "John the Merciful" and "John III Doukas Vatatzes" (Orthodox) *'''[[John IV Laskaris|John IV]]''',{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} [[Roman Emperor]], died 1305, known as "John IV Laskaris" and "John IV Doukas Laskaris" (Orthodox) *'''[[Justinian I]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 565, known as "Justinian the Great" (Lutheran, Orthodox) *'''[[Justinian II]]''',{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} [[Roman Emperor]], died 711, known as "Justinian Rhinotmetos" ("ὁ Ῥινότμητος", "the slit nosed") (Orthodox) *'''[[Ladislaus I of Hungary]]''', in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] "''Szent László''" (Catholic) *'''[[Prince Lazar|Lazar Hrebeljanović]]''', ''Knez'' ("Prince" or "Duke") of [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]], died 1389, known as "Tsar Lazar", canonized by the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] as "''Свети Косовски Великомученик кнез Лазар''" ("Holy Great-Martyr of Kosovo Prince Lazar"), known as "''Свети Цар Лазар''" ("Holy Tsar Lazar") (Serbian Orthodox Church) *'''[[Leo I the Thracian|Leo I]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 474 (Orthodox)<ref>Great [[Synaxarium|Synaxaristes]] {{gr icon}}: ''[http://www.synaxarion.gr/gr/sid/1818/sxsaintinfo.aspx Ὁ Ἅγιος Λέων Μακέλλης ὁ Μέγας].'' 20 Ιανουαρίου. ΜΕΓΑΣ ΣΥΝΑΞΑΡΙΣΤΗΣ.</ref><ref>''[https://www.goarch.org/chapel/saints?contentid=850&PCode=1PF&D=F&DT=4/13/2018 Renewal Friday: Theotokos of the Life-giving Spring].'' [[Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America]]. Retrieved: 14 April 2018.</ref> *'''[[Leopold III, Margrave of Austria]]''' (Catholic) *'''[[Luarsab II of Kartli]]''', martyr (Orthodox) *'''[[Louis IX of France]]''', in French "''St. Louis''" (Catholic) *'''''[[Ludwig IV of Thuringia]]''', husband of [[Elisabeth of Hungary]] (see under "Other royalty and nobility" below), not canonized but revered as a saint in [[Thuringia]], in [[German language|German]] "''Ludwig IV., der Heilige''" ("Ludwig IV the Holy") (unofficially Catholic)'' *'''[[Manuel II Palaiologos|Manuel II]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 1425, known as "Manuel I Palaiologos" and "Manuel the Monk" (Orthodox) *'''[[Marcian]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 457 (Orthodox) *'''[[Mikhail of Tver|Michael of Tver]]''', martyr, [[Grand Prince of Vladimir]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Mirian III of Iberia]]''' *'''[[Neagoe Basarab]]''', King of Wallachia<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/61200]</ref> *'''[[Nicholas II of Russia]]''', Czar of [[Russia]], the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]] canonized him in 1980 as a saint and martyr, the [[synod]] of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] canonized him as a saint and [[passion bearer]] on 14 August 2000, in [[Russian language|Russian]] "''Царь-Мученик Николай II''" ("Tsar-Martyr Nicholas II") and "''Святой Страстотерпец Царь Николай II''" ("Holy Passion-Bearer Tsar Nicholas II") (Orthodox) *'''[[Nikephoros II Phokas|Nikephoros II]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 969, known as "Nikephoros II Phokas" (Orthodox) *'''[[Olaf II of Norway]]''', known as "St. Olav" and "St. Olave", in [[Old Norse language|Old Norse]] "''Oláfr hinn helgi''", in [[Bokmål]] "''Olav den hellige''", in [[Nynorsk]] "''Heilag-Olav''" (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Oswald of Northumbria]]''', died 642, martyr (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[Peter I of Bulgaria]]''' (Orthodox) *'''[[Sigebert III]]''', [[Merovingian]] [[king of Austrasia]], father of St. Dagobert II (Catholic) *'''[[Sigismund of Burgundy]]''' (Catholic) *'''[[Solomon II of Imereti]]''' (Georgian Orthodox) *'''[[Stephen I of Hungary]]''', known as "St. Stephen of Hungary", in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] "''Szent István király''" (Catholic) *'''[[Stephen the Great|Stephen the Great, King of Moldavia]]''', repaused 2 July 1504, known as the "Athlete of Christianity", a patron saint of [[Moldavia]], in [[Romanian language|Romanian]] "''Dreptcredinciosul Voievod Ştefan cel Mare şi Sfânt''" *'''[[Tamar of Georgia]]''', died 1213, known as "Holy Righteous King Tamar" in the [[Georgian Orthodox Church]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Theodosius I]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 395, known as "Theodosius the Great" (Orthodox) *'''[[Theodosius II]]''', [[Roman Emperor]], died 450, known as "Theodosius the Younger" and "Theodosius the Calligrapher" (Orthodox) *'''[[Tiridates III of Armenia]]''', revered as a saint in the [[Armenian Church]] *'''[[Vakhtang I of Iberia]]''' (Georgian Orthodox) *'''[[Vakhtang III of Georgia]]''' (Georgian Orthodox) *'''[[Vladimir I of Kiev]]''', first Christian ruler of [[Kiev]], in the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] his title denotes "equal to the Apostles", in [[Russian language|Russian]] "''Владимир Святой''", in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] "''Володимир Святий''" and "''Святий рівноапостольний князь Володимир''" ("Saint Equal-to-the-Apostles Duke Volodymyr") (Orthodox) *'''[[Wenceslaus I, Duke of Bohemia]]''', died 28 September 935, martyr, patron of the [[Czech Republic]], in [[Czech language|Czech]] "''Svatý Václav''", in [[German language|German]] "''Heilige Wenzel''" (Catholic, Orthodox) *'''[[William of Gellone]]''', Count of Toulouse (Catholic)
===Roman Catholic Beati, Venerabili, and Servants of God===
The [[Roman Catholic Church]] classifies various holy persons who have not been [[canonization|canonized]] as saints in the inferior categories of [[Beatification|beati]], venerabili, and [[servants of God]]. These titles indicate grades on the path to [[canonization]] in that church.
*'''''[[Charlemagne]]''', [[King of the Franks]] and first [[Holy Roman Emperor]], although never validly "[[canonization|canonized]]", his ''[[cult (religion)|cultus]]'' was permitted fully at [[Aachen]]<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03610c.htm Shahan, Thomas, and Ewan Macpherson. "Charlemagne." ''The Catholic Encyclopedia''. Vol. 3. New York, New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1908. 19 February 2013.]</ref> (dubious)'' *'''[[Karl I of Austria|Bl. Karl I of Austria]]''', final [[Kaiser|Emperor]] of [[Austria]] and King of [[Hungary]], known as "Blessed Karl I", "Blessed Karl of Austria", and "Blessed Charles I of Austria", in [[German language|German]] "''Der Selige Kaiser Karl I''", in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] "''Boldog Károly király''"
==Other royalty and nobility==
This section enumerates [[Christian]] [[royal family|royalty]], including [[spouse|consort]]s but not [[sovereign]]s, and [[nobility]]. [[Christian]] [[sovereign]]s, while also "[[royal family|royalty]]", are exclusively enumerated in "Monarchs" above.
===Saints===
*'''[[Adela of Normandy]]''', [[Countess of Blois]], daughter of king [[William I of England]] and mother of king [[Stephen, King of England|Stephen]] (Catholic) *'''[[Adelaide of Italy]]''', [[List of Holy Roman Empresses|empress-consort]] of [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor]] *'''[[Agnes of Bohemia]]''', daughter of [[Otakar I of Bohemia]], in [[Czech language|Czech]] ''"Sv. Anežka Česka"'' *'''[[Alexandra Fyodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Fyodorovna of Russia (Alix of Hesse)]]''' *'''[[Tsarevich Alexei Nikolaevich of Russia|Alexei Nikolaevich of Russia]]''' *'''[[Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia|Anastasia Nikolaevna of Russia]]''' *'''[[Anna of Kashin]]''', wife of Russian Grand Prince [[Mikhail of Tver|St. Mikhail of Tver]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Balthild]]''', Queen of [[France]] and wife of [[King Clovis II]], died 30 January 680 (Catholic) *'''[[Begga]]''', daughter of [[Pepin of Landen]] and mother of [[Pepin of Herstal]] *'''''[[Bertha of Kent]]''', revered as a saint but not canonized'' *'''[[Enravota|Bojan Enravota]]''', Prince of [[Bulgaria]]<ref>[http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/92786]</ref> *'''[[Boris and Gleb|Boris]]''', Prince of [[Kiev]] *'''[[Canute Lavard]]''', Danish prince, son of king [[Eric I of Denmark]] and ancestor of Danish monarchs. *'''[[Saint Casimir|Casimir]]''', son of [[Casimir IV of Poland]], known as "St. Casimir of Poland" and "Saint Casimir Jagiełło", in [[Polish language|Polish]] ''"Święty Kazimierz"'' (Catholic) *'''[[Clotilde]]''', daughter of [[Chilperic II of Burgundy]], wife of [[Clovis I]] *'''[[Prince Constantine Constantinovich of Russia|Constantine Constantinovich]]''', Prince of [[Russia]] *'''[[Cunigunde of Luxemburg]]''', wife of Henry II, in [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]] ''"Helleg Kunigunde"'' *'''[[Tsarevich Dmitry Ivanovich of Russia (born 1582)|Dmitry of Moscow]]''' *'''[[Edburga of Winchester]]''', daughter of [[Edward the Elder]] *'''[[Edburga of Bicester]]''', daughter of [[Penda of Mercia]] *'''[[Edburga of Minster-in-Thanet]]''', or Heaburg, or Bugga, daughter of [[Centwine of Wessex]] *'''[[Ælfgifu of Shaftesbury|Elgiva of Wessex]]''', queen, wife of English king [[Edmund I]] and mother of another two kings. *'''[[Grand Duchess Elizabeth Fyodorovna|Elizabeth Fyodorovna]]''' of [[Russia]] *'''[[Elisabeth of Hungary]]''', wife of [[Ludwig IV of Thuringia]] (see above), in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] ''"Árpádházi Szent Erzsébet"'' ("Saint Elizabeth of Árpád's Line") (Catholic) *'''[[Elizabeth of Portugal]]''', daughter of [[Pedro III of Aragon]], wife of [[Denis of Portugal]], known as "St. Queen Elizabeth" and "St. Isabel of Portugal", in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''"Rainha Santa Isabel"'' (Catholic) *'''[[Emeric of Hungary (saint)|Emeric of Hungary]]''', son of [[Stephen I of Hungary]], in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] ''"Szent Imre"'' *'''[[Queen Emma of Hawaii]]''', who helped to found the [[Anglican Church]] in [[Hawaii]], [[United States]] (Anglican) *'''[[Boris and Gleb|Gleb]]''', Prince of [[Kiev]] *'''[[Hedwig of Andechs]]''', daughter of Berthold III, Count of Tyrol, wife of [[Henry I of Poland]], canonized 1267 as "St. Hedwig of Andechs", in [[Polish language|Polish]] ''"Św. Jadwiga Śląska"'' *'''[[Helena of Constantinople]]''', Roman Empress, died circa 327, mother of [[Constantine I|Emperor Constantine I]] (see above) *'''[[Igor Konstantinovich of Russia|Igor Konstantinovich]]''', Prince of [[Russia]] *'''[[Ingegerd Olofsdotter of Sweden|Ingegerd of Sweden]]''', Grand Princess of Kiev as wife of [[Yaroslav I the Wise]], and Swedish princess as daughter of king [[Olof Skötkonung]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Ioann Konstantinovich of Russia|Ioann Konstantinovich]]''', Prince of [[Russia]] *'''[[Irene of Hungary]]''', Roman Empress, died 1134, consort of [[John II Komnenos|Emperor John II]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Saint Isabelle of France|Isabelle of France]]''', Princess of [[France]], daughter of [[Louis VIII of France]], younger sister of [[Louis IX of France|S.t Louis of France]] (see above) *'''[[Jeanne of France (1464-1505)|Jeanne of France]]''', daughter of [[Louis XI of France]], wife of [[Louis XII of France]], known as "St. Jeanne de Valois", in French ''"Ste Jeanne de France"'' *'''[[Ketevan the Martyr]]''', Queen of [[Kakheti]], canonized by the [[Georgian Orthodox and Apostolic Church|Georgian Church]] (Georgian Orthodox) *'''[[Kinga of Poland]]''', daughter of [[Béla IV of Hungary]], wife of [[Boleslaus V of Poland]], known as "St. Kunigunda", "St. Cunegunde", "St. Kioga", and "St. Zinga", in [[Polish language|Polish]] ''"Święta Kinga"'' (Catholic) *'''[[Saint Ludmila|Ludmila]]''', Czech Princess (Orthodox) *'''[[Saint Margaret of Hungary|Margaret of Hungary]]''', daughter of [[Béla IV of Hungary]], in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] ''"Árpád-házi Szent Margit"'' ("St. Margaret of Árpád's Line") (Catholic) *'''[[Saint Margaret of Scotland|Margaret of Scotland]]''', died 16 November 1093, granddaughter of [[Edmund II of England]], wife of [[Malcolm III of Scotland]], and mother of [[David I of Scotland|King David I of Scotland]] (see above), canonized in 1251 (Catholic) *'''[[Grand Duchess Maria Nikolaevna of Russia (1899–1918)|Maria Nikolaevna of Russia]]''', died 1918 *'''[[Matilda of Ringelheim|Matilda]]''', queen consort of [[Henry the Fowler|Heinrich I of Germany]] (Catholic) *'''[[Nana of Iberia]]''', queen consort of [[Mirian III of Iberia]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Nuno Álvares Pereira]], [[Carmelites|O. Carm.]]''', ancestor of the Portuguese [[House of Braganza]] (Catholic) *'''[[Olga of Kiev]]''', regent of son [[Svyatoslav I, Prince of Kiev]], in [[Russian language|Russian]] ''"Свята Ольга"'' ("Holy Olga") *'''[[Grand Duchess Olga Nikolaevna of Russia|Olga Nikolaevna]]''', Grand Duchess of [[Russia]] *'''[[Pulcheria]]''', Byzantine empress, married emperor [[Marcian]] (Catholic and Orthodox) *'''[[Ragnhild of Tälje]]''' *'''[[Saint Shushanik|Shushanik]]''' (Orthodox) *'''[[Grand Duchess Tatiana Nikolaevna of Russia|Tatiana Nikolaevna]]''', Grand Duchess of [[Russia]] *'''[[Theodora (wife of Theophilos)|Theodora]]''', Roman Empress, died 867, consort of [[Theophilos (emperor)|Emperor Theophilos]] (Orthodox) *'''[[Vladimir Paley]]''', Prince
===Roman Catholic Beati, Venerabili, and Servants of God===
The [[Roman Catholic Church]] classifies various holy persons who have not been [[canonization|canonized]] as saints in the inferior categories of [[Beatification|beati]], venerabili, and [[servants of God]]. These titles indicate grades on the path to [[canonization]] in that church.
*'''[[Isabella I of Castile]]''', Queen of [[Spain]], her cause of beatification has been open since 1958<ref>See link: http://www.reinacatolica.org/causa.html</ref>, but remains a controversial issue in Spain and in the Americas. *'''[[Joana, Crown Princess of Portugal|Bl. Joana of Portugal]]''', Princess of [[Portugal]], daughter of [[Afonso V of Portugal]], [[Dominican Order|Dominican]], known in Portugal as ''Santa Joana Princesa'' ("St. Princess Joan"), although she is beatified only *'''[[Jolenta of Poland|Bl. Jolenta of Poland]]''', died 11 June 1298, daughter of [[Béla IV of Hungary]], wife of [[Boleslaus of Greater Poland|Boleslaus the Pious of Poland]], known as "Blessed Yolanda of Poland", "Blessed Yolande of Poland" and "Blessed Helen of Hungary", in [[Polish language|Polish]] ''"Bł. She was declared a Servant of God and the cause for her canonization remains open.
==Pre-Christian Saints==
[[David|King David]] of the [[Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)|United Monarchy]] of [[ancient Israel]] and Kings [[Hezekiah]] and [[Josiah]] of the southern [[Kingdom of Judah]] are traditionally considered to be in [[Heaven]] by [[Catholic]] dogma.<ref>[http://www.catholic.org/prayers/prayer.php?p=467 "Litany to Old Testament Saints"]</ref><ref>[http://www.catholic.com/thisrock/quickquestions/keyword/Old%20Testament/page4 ''This Rock'' Quick Questions, Volume 14, Issue 5.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114045922/http://www.catholic.com/thisrock/quickquestions/keyword/Old%20Testament/page4 |date=14 January 2010 }}</ref> They are named as saints of the [[Old Testament]] by the [[Orthodox Church]], as numerous calendars, services for their intercession, and the custom of naming them patron saints attest. Some heterodox, however, do not recognise them as saints because they lived before the time of Christ.
