{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Saramaka |image=Saramaka-1910.jpg |image_upright=0.8 |caption=Saramaka man, photo c.1910, from Sir Harry H. Johnson's ''The Negro in the New World'' |total=55,000 |popplace=[[Suriname]] and [[French Guiana]] |rels=Saramaka religion (80%), Christianity: Moravian, Catholic, Evangelical (20%) |langs=[[Saramaccan language|Saramaccan]] |related=Ndyuka, Matawai, Paramaka, Aluku (Boni), Kwinti }}
The '''Saramaka''' or '''Saramacca''' are one of six [[Maroon (people)|Maroon peoples]] (formerly called "Bush Negroes") in the Republic of [[Suriname]] and one of the Maroon peoples in [[French Guiana]]. (Note that beginning in mid-2010, the people formerly known as “Saramaka” began identifying themselves, in their official documents in English, as "Saamaka," to conform to their own pronunciation.) In 2007, the Saramaka won a ruling by the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights|Inter-American Court for Human Rights]] supporting their land rights in Suriname for lands they have historically occupied, over national government claims. It was a landmark decision for indigenous peoples in the world. They have received compensation for damages and control this fund for their own development goals.
The word "Maroon" comes from the Spanish ''cimarrón'', which was derived from an [[Arawakan languages|Arawakan root]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Arrom |first=José |title=Cimarrón: Apuntes sobre sus primeras documentaciones y su probable origen |journal=Revista Española de Antropología Americana |volume=13 |pages=13-30 |year=1986}}</ref> Since 1990 especially, some of the Saramaka have migrated to French Guiana due to extended civil war in Suriname. By the early 16th century, the term "maroon" (''cimarron'') was used throughout the Americas to designate slaves who had escaped from [[slavery]] and set up independent communities beyond colonists' control.<ref>{{cite book |editor-last1=Price |editor-first1=Richard |title=Maroon Societies: Rebel Slave Communities in the Americas |date=1996 |publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press |location=Baltimore, MD |isbn=978-0801854965 |edition=3rd |pages=xi-xii}}</ref> Together with five other Maroon tribes in Suriname and French Guiana, the Saramaka form the largest group in the world of Maroon peoples of African descent.
== Setting and language == Suriname, formerly called Dutch Guiana, has been independent from the Netherlands since 1975. The 90,000 Saramaka (some of whom live in neighboring [[French Guiana]]) are one minority within this multi-ethnic nation, which includes approximately 27 per cent [[Indian people|Hindustanis]] (East Indian descendants of contract laborers brought in after the abolition of slavery); 14.5 per cent [[Afro-Surinamese|Creoles]] (descendants of Africans brought as slaves); 14 per cent [[Javanese people|Javanese]] (descendants of contract workers brought during the early 20th century from [[Indonesia]]); 23.5 per cent Maroons (descendants of Africans brought as slaves); 3 per cent Chinese, [[Levant]]ines, and Europeans; and 3.7 per cent [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Amerindians]].
The Saramaka, together with the other Maroons in Suriname and French Guiana: the [[Ndyuka people|Ndyuka]] (90,000), and the [[Matawai (people)|Matawai]], [[Paramaka]], [[Aluku]], and [[Kwinti]] (who together number some 25,000), constitute by far the world's largest surviving population of Maroons of African descent.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Price |first=Richard |title=The Maroon Population Explosion: Suriname and Guyane |journal=New West Indian Guide |volume=87 |issue=3/4 |year=2013 |pages=323-327}}</ref>
Since their escape from [[slavery]] in the 17th and 18th centuries, the Saramaka have lived chiefly along the upper [[Suriname River]] and its tributaries, the Gaánlío and the Pikílío. Since the 1960s, they also live along the lower Suriname River in villages constructed by the [[Colonialism|colonial government]] and [[Alcoa]], a major aluminum company. They were relocated to allow flooding of approximately half their tribal territory for a [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric project]] built to supply electricity for an [[aluminum]] [[Smelting|smelter]]. Today, about one-third of the Saramaka live in French Guiana, most having migrated there since 1990 after warfare in Suriname.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |last2=Price |first2=Sally |title=Les Marrons |date=2003 |publisher=Vents d'Ailleurs |location=Chateauneuf-le-Rouge |isbn=978-2911412226}}</ref>
The Saramaka and the Matawai (in central Suriname) speak variants of a [[creole language]] called [[Saramaccan language|Saramaccan]]. The Ndyuka, Paramaka, and Aluku, (in eastern Suriname), as well as the several hundred Kwinti, speak variants of another creole language, [[Ndyuka language|Ndyuka]]. Both languages are historically related to [[Sranan Tongo]], the creole language of coastal Suriname. About 50 percent of the Saramaccan [[lexicon]] derives from various West and Central African languages, 20 percent from English (the language of the original colonists in Suriname), 20 percent from [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (the language of the overseers and slave masters on many Suriname [[plantation]]s), and the remaining 10 percent from Amerindian languages and [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (the latter were later colonists).<ref>Richard Price, ''Travels with Tooy: History, Memory, and the African American Imagination'', Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2008, p. 436.</ref> Although lexically different, the grammar resembles that of the other Atlantic creoles and derives from West African models.<ref>{{cite journal |editor-last=Migge |editor-first=Bettina |title=Substrate Influence in the Creoles of Suriname |url=http://linguistics.osu.edu/sites/linguistics.osu.edu/files/dissertations/Migge1998.pdf |journal=Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages |volume=22 |issue=1 |year=2007}}</ref>
== History == The ancestors of the Saramaka were among those Africans sold as plantation [[slaves]] to Europeans in Suriname in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.<ref name="Slay Hydra"/>{{rp|1}} Coming from a variety of West and Central African peoples speaking many different languages, they escaped into the dense [[rainforest]] – individually, in small groups, and sometimes in great collective rebellions. For nearly 100 years, they fought from the rainforest for their independence. They were so feared that late 18th century maps showed the defensive fortifications in the European colony intended to protect against their raids.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/524/ |title=Extract of the Dutch Map Representing the Colony of Surinam |year=1777 |website=Digital World Library |publisher=Library of Congress |accessdate=26 May 2013}}</ref>
In 1762, a full century before the general [[emancipation]] of slaves in Suriname, the Maroons won their freedom and signed a treaty with the Dutch Crown to acknowledge their territorial rights and trading privileges. The Saramaka have a keen interest in the history of their formative years; they preserve their very rich [[oral tradition]]. Innovative scholarly research since the late 20th century has brought together oral and archival accounts in new histories.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |title=First-time: The Historical Vision of an Afro-American People |date=1983 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |location=Baltimore |isbn=9780801829857}}</ref><ref name="Slay Hydra">{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |title=To Slay the Hydra: Dutch Colonial Perspectives on the Saramaka Wars |date=1983 |publisher=Karoma |location=Ann Arbor, MI |isbn=9780897200660}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Price|first1=Richard|title=Alabi's World|date=1995|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore|isbn=9780801838620}}</ref> Like the other Suriname Maroons, the Saramaka lived almost as a state-within-a-state until the mid-20th century, when the pace of outside encroachments increased.
During the late 1980s, a civil war between Maroons and the military government of Suriname caused considerable hardship to the Saramaka and other Maroons. By mid-1989 approximately 3,000 Saramaka and 8,000 Ndyuka were living as temporary refugees in French Guiana. Access to the outside world was severely restricted for many Saramaka in their homeland.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Polimé |first1=Thomas |last2=van Velzen |first2=H.U.E. Thoden |title=Vluchtelingen, opstandelingen en andere: Bosnegers van Oost-Suriname, 1986-1988 |date=1988 |publisher=Instituut voor Culturele Antropologie |location=Utrecht |isbn=9789070955229}}</ref> The end of the war in the mid-1990s initiated a period in which the national government largely neglected the needs of Saramaka and other Maroons while granting large timber and mining concessions to foreign multinationals (Chinese, Indonesian, Malaysian, and others) in traditional Saramaka territory. They did not consult the Saramaka authorities.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kambel |first1=Ellen-Rose |last2=MacKay |first2=Fergus |title=The Rights of Indigenous Peoples and Maroons of Suriname |date=1999 |publisher=International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs |location=Copenhagen |isbn=978-8790730178}}</ref>
In addition, during this period there were numerous social changes, both on the coast of Suriname and in Saramaka territory. [[Peace Corps|United States Peace Corps]] volunteers lived and worked in Saramaka villages, and [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]] gold-miners arrived on the Suriname river. Such economic activities as prostitution, casino gambling, and drug smuggling became major industries in coastal Suriname and accompanied the miners to the interior.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Westoll |first1=Andrew |title=The Riverbones: Stumbling After Eden in the Jungles of Suriname |date=2008 |publisher=Emblem |location=Toronto, Canada |isbn=978-0771088759}}</ref>
In the mid-1990s, the Association of Saramaka Authorities filed a complaint before the [[Inter-American Commission on Human Rights|Inter-American Commission of Human Rights]] to protect their [[land rights]]. In November 2007, the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights|Inter-American Court for Human Rights]] ruled in favor of the Saramaka people against the government of Suriname.<ref name="Case Judgment">{{cite web |url=http://www.corteidh.or.cr/docs/casos/articulos/seriec_172_ing.pdf |title=Case of the Saramaka People v. Suriname, Judgment of November 28, 2007 |publisher=Inter-American Court of Human Rights (La Corte Interamericana de Derechos Humanos) |accessdate=21 May 2009}}</ref> In this landmark decision, which establishes a precedent for all Maroon and [[indigenous peoples]] in the Americas, the Saramaka were granted collective rights to the lands on which their ancestors had lived since the early 18th century, including rights to decide about the exploitation of [[natural resource]]s such as timber and [[gold]] within that territory. In addition, they were granted compensation from the government for damages caused by previous timber grants made to Chinese companies. This was paid into a special [[Community development|development]] fund, which is now managed by the Saramaka.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |title=Rainforest Warriors Human Rights on Trial |year=2012 |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |location=Pennsylvania |isbn=9780812221374}}</ref><ref name="Case Judgment"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brunner |first1=Lisl |title=The Rise of Peoples' Rights in the Americas: The Saramaka People Decision of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights |journal=Chinese Journal of International Law |date=1 October 2008 |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=699–711 |doi=10.1093/chinesejil/jmn031}}</ref>
== Subsistence, economy, and the arts == [[File:Maroon Art - Museum - Nieuw Amsterdam (23624931402).jpg|alt=Example of art by the Saramaka folk|thumb|281x281px|Example of art by the Saramaka folk]] Traditional villages, which average 100 to 200 residents, consist of a core of [[Matrilineality|matrilineal kin]] plus some wives and children of lineage men.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |title=Saramaka Social Structure: Analysis of a Maroon Society in Surinam |date=1975 |publisher=Institute of Caribbean Studies, University of Puerto Rico |location=Río Piedras |isbn=9788439938507}}</ref> Always located near a river, for water, transportation and fishing, they are constructed of an irregular arrangement of small houses, open-sided structures, domesticated trees, occasional chicken houses, various [[shrine]]s, and scattered patches of bush. (In contrast, the so-called transmigration villages, built to house the 6,000 Saramaka displaced by the hydroelectric project, range up to 2,000 people. They are laid out in a European-style [[Grid plan|grid pattern]], used throughout larger South American cities. In many cases they have been located far from the riverside, making life difficult for the occupants.) [[Horticulture|Horticultural camps]], which include permanent houses and shrines, are located several hours by [[canoe]] from each village. They are exploited by small groups of women related through matrilineal ties.
Due to their matrilineal ties, many women have a house in their own birth village, another in their horticultural camp, and a third in their husband's village. Men divide their time among several different houses, built at various times for themselves and for their wives. Traditional Saramaka houses are compact, wide enough to tie a hammock and not much longer from front to back; with walls of planks and woven [[palm branch (symbol)|palm fronds]], and traditionally roofs of [[thatch]] or, increasingly, of [[Corrugated galvanised iron|corrugated metal]]. They do not have windows but often have elaborately carved [[facade]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Sally |last2=Price |first2=Richard |title=Maroon Arts: Cultural Vitality in the African Diaspora |date=1999 |publisher=Beacon Press |location=Boston |isbn=9780807085509}}</ref> Since the Suriname civil war, the Saramaka have built an increasing number of houses in coastal, Western style. They use [[concrete]] as well as wood, and feature windows and more expansive [[floor plan]]s.
For more than two centuries, the economy has been based on full exploitation of the forest environment and on periodic work trips by men to the coast to bring back Western goods. For subsistence, the Saramaka depend on shifting ([[Slash and burn|swidden]]) horticulture done mostly by women, with hunting and fishing done by men, supplemented by the women gathering wild forest products, such as palm nuts. They imported a few key items, such as [[salt]]. [[Rice]] is the most cultivated crop, in dry (hillside) technique. Other crops include [[cassava]], [[taro]], [[okra]], [[maize]], [[Plantain (cooking)|plantain]]s, [[banana]]s, [[sugarcane]], and [[peanut]]s. Domesticated trees, such as [[coconut]], [[Orange (fruit)|orange]], [[breadfruit]], [[papaya]], and [[calabash]] are mainly cultivated in the villages. There are no markets.
Until the late 20th century, the Saramaka produced most of their material culture, much of it embellished with decorative detail. Women sewed [[patchwork]] and embroidered clothing, and carved [[calabash]] bowls. Some men also produced baskets, and some women made pottery. Men built the houses and canoes. In addition, they carved a wide range of wooden objects for domestic use, such as stools, paddles, [[Winnowing|winnowing trays]], cooking utensils, and combs. Today, an increasing number of items, including clothing, are imported from the coast.
Body [[Scarification|cicatrization]], practiced by virtually all Saramaka women as late as the 1970s and 1980s, had become relatively uncommon by the start of the 21st century. Numerous genres of singing, dance, drumming, and tale telling continue to be a vibrant part of Saramaka culture.<ref>For examples of popular songs, work songs, finger piano pieces, children's riddles, drum language on the ''apínti'' talking drum, and more, see {{cite AV media |author1-last=Price |author1-first=Richard |author2-last=Price |author2-first=Sally |year=1977 |title=Music from Saramaka: A Dynamic Afro American Tradition |medium=CD |location=Washington, DC |publisher=Smithsonian/Folkways Recordings |oclc=50625762}}</ref>
Once the men have cleared and burned the fields, horticulture is mainly women's work. Women cultivate and process a variety of crops, choosing which to develop to continue preferred qualities. They process the food for meals and storage of foods such as peanuts. They use parts of plants to make some needed goods.
The men conduct hunting of game with [[shotgun]]s; they also do most of the fishing as well. Men have long devoted a large portion of their adult years to earning money in work in coastal Suriname or French Guiana. This allows them to buy the Western goods considered essential to life in their home villages, such as shotguns and [[Gunpowder|powder]], tools, pots, cloth, hammocks, soap, [[kerosene]], and [[rum]]. During the second half of the 20th century, small stores were established in many villages, making more goods available. [[Outboard motor]]s, [[transistor radio]]s, and [[tape recorder]]s became common consumer items. Today, [[Mobile phone|cell phones]] are ubiquitous; both men and women have greatly increased communication with [[Paramaribo]]. New economic opportunities in the gold industry – mining for men, prostitution for women – are being exploited.
== Social organization == Saramaka society is firmly based on a matrilineal [[kinship system]]. A [[clan]] (''lo'') – often several thousand individuals – consists of the matrilineal descendants of an original [[Band society|band]] of escaped slaves. Children are considered born into this clan. It is subdivided into [[Lineage (anthropology)|lineages]] (''bee'') – usually 50 to 150 people – descended from a more recent ancestress. Several lineages from a single clan constitute the core of every village.
The matrilineal clans (''lo'') own land, based on claims staked out in the early 18th century as the original Maroons fled southward to [[Liberty|freedom]]. Hunting and gathering rights belong to clan members collectively. Within the clan, temporary rights to land use for farming are negotiated by village headmen. The establishment of transmigration villages in the 1960s led to land shortages in certain regions. The success of the Saramakas in their [[lawsuit]] against the government of Suriname will now permit them to manage their lands with less outside interference.
Complex marriage prohibitions (including ''bee'' [[exogamy]]) and preferences are negotiated through [[divination]]. Demographic imbalance, owing to labor migration, permits widespread [[polygyny]]. Although co-wives hold equal status, relations between them are expected to be adversarial. The Saramaka treat marriage as an ongoing [[courtship]], with frequent exchanges of gifts such as men's [[woodcarving]] and women's decorative sewing. Although many women live primarily in their husband's village, men never spend more than a few days at a time in the matrilineal (home) village of a wife.<ref>{{cite book |last=Price |first=Sally |title=Co-wives and Calabashes |date=1984 |publisher=University of Michigan Press |location=Ann Arbor |isbn=9780472100453}}</ref>
Each house belongs to an individual man or woman, but most [[social interaction]] occurs outdoors. The men in each cluster of several houses, whether ''bee'' members or temporary visitors, eat meals together. The women of these same clusters, whether ''bee'' members or resident wives of ''bee'' men, spend a great deal of time in each other's company, often farming together as well.
Matrilineal principles, mediated by divination, determine the inheritance of material and spiritual possessions as well as [[Politician|political offices]]. Before death, however, men often pass on specialized [[ritual]] knowledge (and occasionally a shotgun) to a son.
Each child, after spending its first several years with its mother, is raised by an individual man or woman (not a couple) designated by the ''bee'', girls typically are raised by women, and boys by men. Although children spend most of their time with matrilineal kin, father-child relations are warm and strong. [[Gender identity]] is established early, with children taking on responsibility for gender-typed adult tasks as soon as they are physically able. Girls often marry by age 15, whereas boys are more often in their twenties when they take their first wife.
A woman is required to go into seclusion during her menstrual cycle. The cycle is considered a time of transgression and destructive of village order. Women are not allowed to perform many of the village's functions and face other restrictions during their menstrual cycle. The Saramaka expression "to be in menstrual seclusion" is the same as "to be in mourning."<ref>{{cite book |last=Price |first=Sally |title=Co-Wives and Calabashes |year=1996 |publisher=The University Michigan Press |location=United States |pages=xi-xii}}</ref>
== Political organization and social control == The Saramaka people, like the other Maroon groups, are politically and formally run by men. The 2007 ruling of the Inter-American Court for Human Rights helps define the spheres of influence in which the national government and Saramaka authorities hold sway.
Saramaka [[society]] is [[egalitarian]], with [[kinship]] forming the backbone of [[social organization]]. No social or occupational [[Social class|classes]] are distinguished. Elders are accorded special respect and ancestors are consulted, through [[divination]], on a daily basis.
[[Missionary|Protestant missionary schools]] have existed in some villages since the 18th century. State [[elementary school]]s came to most villages only in the 1960s. Schools ceased to function completely during the Suriname civil war of the late 1980s and have been rebuilt only partially since.
Since the 18th-century treaty, the Saramaka have had a government-approved [[paramount chief]] (''gaamá''), as well as a series of headmen (''kabiteni'') and assistant headmen (''basiá''). Traditionally, the role of these officials in political and social control was exercised in a context replete with [[oracle]]s, [[spirit possession]], and other forms of divination. As the national government is intervening more frequently in Saramaka affairs (and paying political officials nominal salaries), the sacred base of these officials’ power is gradually being eroded. These political offices are historically controlled and the property of [[clans]] (''lo''). Political activity is strongly dominated by men.
Council meetings (''kuútu'') and divination sessions provide complementary arenas for the resolution of social problems. Palavers may involve the men of a lineage, a village, or all Saramaka. They treat problems ranging from conflicts concerning marriage or [[fosterage]] to land disputes, political succession, or major crimes. These same problems, in addition to illness and other kinds of misfortune, are routinely interpreted through various kinds of divination as well. In all cases, consensus is found through negotiation, often with a strong role being played by [[Polytheism|gods]] and ancestors. In a type of reconciliation justice, guilty parties are usually required to pay for their misdeeds with material offerings to the lineage of the offended person. In the 18th century people found guilty of [[witchcraft]] were sometimes burned at the stake. Today, men caught [[in flagrante delicto]] with the wife of another man are either beaten by the woman's kinsmen or made to pay them a fine.
Aside from adultery disputes, which sometimes mobilize a full canoe-load of men seeking revenge in a public fistfight, intra-Saramaka conflict rarely surpasses the level of personal relations. The civil war that began in 1986, pitting Maroons against the national army of Suriname, brought major changes to the villages of the interior. Members of the "Jungle Commando" rebel army, almost all [[Ndyuka people|Ndyuka]] and Saramaka, learned to use [[Automatic firearm|automatic weapons]]. They became accustomed to a [[Perpetual war|state of war]] and plunder. Their reintegration into Saramaka (and Ndyuka) society has been difficult, though their migration to the coast and French Guiana has provided a [[safety valve]], if not for the receiving areas.
== Belief system == Every aspect of Saramaka [[Phenomenological life|life]] is based in various [[religious]] beliefs.<ref>Richard Price, ''Travels with Tooy: History, Memory, and the African American Imagination'', Chicago, University of Chicago Press, 2008.</ref> Such decisions as where to clear a garden or build a house, whether to undertake a trip, or how to deal with theft or adultery are made in consultation with village deities, ancestors, forest [[spirit]]s, and [[Snake worship|snake gods]]. The means of communication with these powers vary from spirit possession and the consultation of oracle-bundles, to the interpretation of dreams. Gods and spirits, which are a constant presence in daily life, are also honored through frequent [[prayer]]s, [[libation]]s, feasts, and dances.
The [[ritual]]s surrounding birth, death, and other life passages are extensive, as are those relating to more mundane activities, from hunting a [[tapir]] to planting a rice field. Today about 25 per cent of Saramaka are nominal Christians – mainly [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] (some since the mid-18th century), but others [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]. Increasingly some are converted to [[Evangelicalism]] of one or another kind.
The Saramaka world is populated by a wide range of [[supernatural]] beings, from localized forest spirits and gods that reside in the bodies of snakes, [[vulture]]s, [[jaguar]]s, and other animals, to ancestors, river gods, and warrior spirits. Within these categories, each supernatural being is named, individualized, and given specific relationships to living people. Intimately involved in the ongoing events of daily life, these beings communicate to humans mainly through divination and spirit possession. ''Kúnus'' are the avenging spirits of people or gods who were wronged during their lifetime and who pledge themselves to eternally tormenting the matrilineal descendants and close matrilineal kinsmen of their offender. Much of Saramaka ritual life is devoted to their appeasement. The Saramaka believe that all [[evil]] originates in human action; not only does each misfortune, illness, or death stem from a specific past misdeed, but every offense, whether against people or gods, has eventual consequences. The ignoble acts of the dead intrude daily on the lives of the living; any illness or misfortune calls for divination, which quickly reveals the specific past act that caused it. Through the performance of [[rite]]s, the ancestors speak, the gods dance, and the world is again made right.
Individual specialists who supervise rites oversee the major village- and clan-owned [[shrine]]s that serve large numbers of clients, as well as the various categories of possession gods, and various kinds of minor divination. These specialists generally pass on their knowledge to selected individuals before death. A large proportion of Saramaka have some kind of specialized ritual expertise, which they occasionally exercise. They are paid in cloth, [[rum]], or, increasingly, cash.
Saramaka [[Ceremony|ceremonial life]] is not determined by the calendar, but rather regulated by the occurrence of particular misfortunes, interpreted through divination. The most important ceremonies include those surrounding funerals and the appeasement of ancestors, public curing rites, rituals in honor of ''kúnus'' (in particular snake gods and forest spirits), and the installation of political officials.
Every case of illness is believed to have a specific cause that can be determined only through divination. The causes revealed vary from a lineage ''kúnu'' to [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]], from a broken [[taboo]] to an ancestor's displeasure. Once the cause is known, rites are carried out to appease the offended god or ancestor (or otherwise right the social imbalance). Since the 1960s, Western mission clinics and hospitals have been used by most Saramaka as a supplement to their own healing practices. During the Suriname Civil War of the 1980s and 1990s, most of these facilities were destroyed. They have only been very partially restored since.
The dead play an active role in the lives of the living. Ancestor shrines – several to a village – are the site of frequent prayers and libations, as the dead are consulted about ongoing village problems. A death occasions a series of complex rituals that lasts about a year, culminating in the final passage of the deceased to the status of ancestor. The initial rites, which are carried out over a period of one week to three months, depending on the importance of the deceased, end with the burial of the corpse in an elaborately constructed [[coffin]] filled with personal belongings. These rites include divination with the coffin (to consult the spirit of the deceased) by carrying it on the heads of two men, feasts for the ancestors, all-night drum/song/dance performances, and the telling of [[Folklore|folktale]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |last2=Bilby |first2=Sally Price |title=Two Evenings in Saramaka |date=1991 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |isbn=9780226680613}}</ref> Some months later, a "second funeral" is conducted to mark the end of the [[Mourning|mourning period]] and to chase the [[ghost]] of the deceased from the village forever. These rites involve the largest public gatherings in Saramaka and also include all-night drum/song/dance performances. At their conclusion, the deceased has passed out of the realm of the living into that of the ancestors.
== Isolation == The Saramaka people beyond Gaan Lio lived in relative isolation and as an [[Uncontacted peoples|uncontacted people group]] from the time of their ancestor's escape from slavery in the eighteenth century.<ref>{{Cite web|title = TRIP DOWN MEMORY LANE: SARAMAKA (SARAMACCAN) PEOPLE: THE FEARLESS SURINAME LARGEST MAROON TRIBE|url = http://kwekudee-tripdownmemorylane.blogspot.com/2013/06/saramaka-saramaccan-people-fearless.html|website = TRIP DOWN MEMORY LANE|date = 2013-06-25|accessdate = 2015-10-07}}</ref> In the latter part of 1993, a local, independent missionary by the name of Steve Groseclose and a small group of Saramaka men from other less remote villages ventured beyond the main barrier point called Tapa Wata Sula, translated as Shut Off Rapids. This initial excursion led to subsequent trips and began the gradual influx of increasing outside influence throughout the following years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = TRIP DOWN MEMORY LANE: SARAMAKA (SARAMACCAN) PEOPLE: THE FEARLESS SURINAME LARGEST MAROON TRIBE|url = http://kwekudee-tripdownmemorylane.blogspot.com/2013/06/saramaka-saramaccan-people-fearless.html|website = TRIP DOWN MEMORY LANE|date = 2013-06-25|accessdate = 2015-10-07}}</ref> A local Saramaka man named Pompeia had left one of the uncontacted villages to visit the capital city of [[Paramaribo]] earlier that year. His knowledge of the villages beyond Tapa Wata Sula made him an invaluable guide on the first trips into the area.
== Ethnographic studies == [[Ethnography]] among the Saramaka was first conducted by Americans [[Melville J. Herskovits|Melville and Frances Herskovits]] (during two summers in 1928 and 1929).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Melville J Herskovits |last2=Frances S. Herskovits |title=Rebel Destiny: Among the Bush Negroes of Dutch Guiana |location=New York and London |publisher=McGraw-Hill |oclc=1114525 |year=1934}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Price |first1=Richard |last2=Price |first2=Sally |title=The Root of Roots: Or, How Afro-American Anthropology Got its Start |date=2003 |publisher=Prickly Paradigm |location=Chicago, Ill. |isbn=9780972819626}}</ref> Americans [[Richard Price (American anthropologist)|Richard]] and [[Sally Price]] have also studied the people (intermittently between 1966 and the present: in Suriname until 1986, and in [[French Guiana]] thereafter). This late-20th century fieldwork complements the modern fieldwork carried out among other groups of Suriname Maroons, such as the [[Ndyuka people|Ndyuka]] ethnography of Dutch scholars [[Bonno]] and Ineke Thoden van Velzen.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Velzen |first1=H.U.E. Thoden van |last2=Wetering |first2=W. van |title=The Great Father and the Danger: Religious Cults, Material Forces, and Collective Fantasies in the World of the Surinamese Maroons |date=1988 |publisher=Foris Publications |location=Dordrecht, Holland |isbn=9789067652346}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Wetering |first1=H.U.E. Thoden van |last2=Velzen |first2=W. van Velzen |title=In the Shadow of the Oracle: Religion as Politics in a Suriname Maroon Society |year=2004 |publisher=Waveland Press |location=Long Grove, Ill. |isbn=9781577663232}}</ref>
[[Edward C. Green]], an American medical anthropologist, conducted fieldwork among the Matawais between 1970–73, with intermittent visits since. His doctoral dissertation focused on changes underway then in the matrilineal kinship and indigenous spiritual belief systems. He has become known for his work on processes related to AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, especially in African nations, and making use of indigenous healers.

{{Infobox Politician | name = Tarapatie Oedayraj Singh Varma |native_name = टरपती उदय राज सिंह वर्मा | image = Tara Singh Varma (1986).jpg | caption = | office = | primeminister = | term_start = | term_end = | predecessor = | term_start1 = | term_end1 = | birth_name = Tarapatie Oedayraj Singh Varma | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|08|29|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Corriverton|Springlands]], [[British Guiana]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[GroenLinks|GreenLeft]] | spouse = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | religion = | signature = | website = }} '''Tarapatie "Tara" Oedayraj Singh Varma''' (born in [[Corriverton|Springlands]] ([[British Guiana]]), August 29, 1948) is a former Dutch politician and former member of the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]] for the [[GroenLinks|GreenLeft party]] who gained notoriety after falsely claiming to suffer from an incurable cancer.
== Life before politics == Although she was born in British Guiana, she attended vocational education in [[Surinam]], which was a [[Dutch empire|colony of the Netherlands]] at the time, studying [[teaching]] and [[law]], without graduating. She then moved to [[Amsterdam]], in the continental part of the [[Netherlands]]. In Amsterdam she became active for the [[Communist Party of the Netherlands]]. Between 1982 and 1994 she was member of the Amsterdam [[gemeenteraad|municipal council]] for the CPN, between 1986 and 1990 for the Left Accord, a common list of the [[Pacifist Socialist Party]] and the [[Political Party of Radicals]], and between 1990 and 1994 for [[GreenLeft]], which was formed by a merger of CPN, PSP, PPR, and the small [[Evangelical People's Party (Netherlands)|Evangelical People's Party]].
Singh Varma was very active in civil society. She was a member various boards of associations and foundations for migrants, women and other social groups. She founded and led an Amsterdam information point. She had a column in the women's weekly ''Furore'', and was a member of the radio panel of the [[Omroepvereniging VARA|VARA]] radio show Punch. She also was treasurer of the Grenada Committee.
== Political life == After the [[Dutch general election, 1994|1994 election]], Singh Varma became a member of the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]]. She succeeded [[Ina Brouwer]], who had stepped down after the poor election results. She was the first female member of the House of Representatives who was not born in the Netherlands. When she entered parliament questions were raised about her integrity. There were questions surrounding [[fundraising]] efforts for the Grenada Foundation in which Singh Varma was involved. A committee led by former minister [[Dieuwke de Graaff-Nauta]] came to the conclusion that Singh Varma had not embezzled money, but that her actions as [[treasurer]] had been neglectful. In parliament Singh Varma spoke on home affairs, health, and welfare. She paid particular attention to the position of migrant women. While in parliament she took many positions outside of parliament in boards of foundations and associations for migrants, women and other social groups. She chaired the Surinam Women's Council and was member of the board of the Volunteer Centre in Amsterdam, the migrant women centre Zami, and the [[prostitute]]s' [[trade union]] the Red Thread. In 1996 she claimed to be intimidated and attacked by [[far right]] groups. No proof of this was ever found.
In 1997 she was put on the ninth place on the GreenLeft list for the [[Dutch general election, 1998|1998 election]]. The committee for candidacy stated that she "did not excel in parliamentary work,"{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} but because of the unexpectedly good election result for the GreenLeft she was re-elected. She also got a large number of [[voorkeursstem|preference votes]]. In 1998 she was a member of the parliamentary inquiry committee on the airplane crash in the [[Bijlmermeer]]. This position got her national fame.
=== Singh Varma Affair === In 2000 Singh Varma claimed that she was less able to perform her work as Member of Parliament. Twice she appeared in the House of Representatives in a wheelchair. She claimed to suffer from an incurable form of cancer and announced that she would leave the House of Representatives to prepare for the end of her life.
In June 2001 the [[TROS]] television show ''[[Opgelicht?!]]'' (in English ''Framed?!'') discovered that Singh Varma did not suffer from cancer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tros.nl/index.php?id=1329 |title=Tara Singh Varma |accessdate=2008-02-02 |author= |work= |publisher=[[TROS]] Opgelicht? !|quote=In totaal tien mensen, van wie de meesten Tara Singh Varma heel goed kennen, verklaren tegenover Opgelicht ! dat ze niet in de ziekte geloven. Ze dragen een groot aantal dingen aan die daar op zouden wijzen. Een paar voorbeelden: op de dag dat Tara in een rolstoel naar de kamer ging, was haar voormalige vriendin die ochtend nog bij haar geweest. De avond daarvoor waren ze flink wezen stappen, en de avond nadat Tara met de rolstoel naar de kamer was gegaan was ze weer kiplekker.Wanneer mensen in haar directe omgeving naar haar behandelend artsen vroegen kregen ze nooit een direct antwoord. Ze noemde ooit drie artsen, maar twee van hen bestonden niet, en de derde kende haar niet. Met een andere vriendin ging ze 's ochtends nadat ze volgens eigen zeggen een chemokuur had gehad, naar het reisbureau om een reis naar India te boeken. [...] Dit zou de gebeurtenis zijn die heeft geleid tot de ontdekking dat Tara Singh Varma kanker had. |language=Dutch}}</ref><ref name="DNPP2001">{{cite journal |last=Lucardie |first=Paul |authorlink=Paul Lucardie |author2=B. de Boer |author3=I. Noomen |author4=G. Voerman |title=Kroniek 2001. Overzicht van de partijpolitieke gebeurtenissen van het jaar 2001 |journal=Jaarboek DNPP |publisher=DNPP |location=Groningen |year=2002 |url=http://www.rug.nl/dnpp/jaarboeken/jaarboek2001/index |accessdate=2008-04-28}}</ref> Moreover, according to this program, Singh Varma had not fulfilled financial promises to the [[India]]n [[development cooperation|development organization]] [[Ninash Foundation]], which had put the organization into financial problems.
First Singh Varma denied both claims and sued the journalists. In August 2001 she claimed that she had not suffered from cancer and instead suffered from [[post traumatic stress disorder]] after self-fabricated [[far right]] threats and her commitment to the victims of the plane crash in the Bijlmermeer. In 2002 she publicly apologized for her actions. She denied lying on purpose about her diseases and stated that she suffered from delusions and medical condition called [[pseudologia fantastica]].<ref name="parlement.com">{{Cite web |title=T. Oedayraj Singh Varma |url=http://www.parlement.com/9291000/biof/02532 |accessdate=2008-04-29}}</ref> [[Paul Rosenmöller]], political leader of the [[GreenLeft]] at the time writes that he felt "cheated and angry" because of her revelations.<ref>[[Paul Rosenmöller]] (2003), ''Een mooie hondenbaan'', Amsterdam: Balans, p. 234</ref>
== Life after politics == After leaving parliament Singh Varma became editor of the People's Newspaper Suriname around 2005. Later she worked in a Surinam deli.<ref name="parlement.com"/>

The '''50% Rule''' in English [[Faith school|Faith School]] admissions was introduced in 2010 and stipulates that where newly established [[Academies (England)|Academies]] with a religious character are oversubscribed, at least 50% of their places must be '''open places''', i.e. allocated without reference to faith. The rule is sometimes referred to as the '''Faith Cap''' on admissions.<ref name=TES>{{cite news |last=George |first=Martin |date=23 November 2017 |title=Bishops launch petition to lift faith school cap |url=https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/bishops-launch-petition-lift-faith-school-cap |work=TES |location= |access-date=30 December 2017}}</ref><ref name=CT>{{cite news |last=Davies |first=Madeleine |date=28 July 2017 |title=Faith cap ‘will not affect our schools’ |url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2017/28-july/news/uk/faith-cap-will-not-affect-our-schools |work=Church Times |location= |access-date=30 December 2017}}</ref> However, as the open places are just as accessible to faith applicants as non-faith applicants, in practice the rule does not explicitly prevent such schools from having more than 50% of students with a faith affiliation.<ref name="ADA2638"/><ref name="Hansard30April2014"/>
The 50% Rule applies only to ''new'' academies, established under the [[Free school (England)|Free School]] programme, not to maintained schools that have converted to academy status.<ref name="AdmissionsCode">{{cite web|title=School Admissions Code - December 2014|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/school-admissions-code--2|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref>
== Rationale == [[David Laws#Return to government|David Laws, Schools Minister]] at the time the 50% Rule was introduced, described the motivation behind it in a Parliamentary debate.<ref name="Hansard30April2014"/> He said: "Where the Government fund new Church or faith school provision, it is right that such new schools cater for local demand in the faith, but the needs of children in the broader local community must not be overlooked. We want all local children to have the same opportunity to access high-quality state-funded education. The fact that it is state funded is the point."
He went on to talk about the principle of parental choice, saying there are "two competing rights in a state-funded school system: people’s right to choose to have their children educated in the way that they wish, and the right of [other] taxpayers who live near state-funded schools to have some ability to access them despite the over-representation of people from the faith that the system allows."
== History == The 50% Rule was introduced by the [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|2010 Coalition Government]] formed from the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]]. In the run up to the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 General Election]], the Liberal Democrat manifesto had stated that "We will ensure that all faith schools develop an inclusive admissions policy."<ref name="LibDemManifesto2010">{{cite web|title=Liberal Democrat Manifesto 2010|url=http://www.politicsresources.net/area/uk/ge10/man/parties/libdem_manifesto_2010.pdf|publisher=Liberal Democrats|accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref> This aim was reflected in the [[Conservative–Liberal Democrat coalition agreement|Coalition Agreement]] as follows: "We will ensure that all new Academies follow an inclusive admissions policy. We will work with faith groups to enable more faith schools and facilitate inclusive admissions policies in as many of these schools as possible."<ref name="LibDemConsCoalitionAgreement">{{cite web|title=The Coalition: our programme for government|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/78977/coalition_programme_for_government.pdf|website=Gov.uk|accessdate=26 August 2017}}</ref>
The 50% Rule was first applied following the [[Academies Act 2010]], via a condition to the Funding Agreements for all new faith academies established under the Free School programme.<ref name="FirstFreeSchools2011BBC">{{cite news|title=The free schools set to open in 2011|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-13810941|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=BBC|date=1 September 2011}}</ref> It was later documented within the 2014 Schools Admissions Code.<ref name="AdmissionsCode" /> The [[Michael Gove#Secretary of State for Education 2010–2014|Education Secretary, Michael Gove]], suggested that the rule should also be "voluntarily" applied to other types of new faith school.<ref name="GoveGuardian30Mar2012">{{cite news|last1=Paton|first1=Graeme|title=Gove backs 50pc limit on faith school admissions|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/9176923/Gove-backs-50pc-limit-on-faith-school-admissions.html|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Guardian|date=30 March 2012}}</ref>
The [[Catholic Education Service]] lobbied for removal of the 50% Rule, saying that they would not open any Free schools while it was in place.<ref name="BCEWStatement2013">{{cite web|title=Statement: Admissions to Catholic Schools|url=http://www.cbcew.org.uk/CBCEW-Home/The-Bishops/Bishops-Plenary-Meetings/Plenary-November-2013/School-Admissions|website=Birshops Conference of England and Wales|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph27Nov2012">{{cite news|last1=Bingham|first1=John|title=Catholic Church snub to Michael Gove's flagship free schools plans|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/9704078/Catholic-Church-snub-to-Michael-Goves-flagship-free-schools-plans.html|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=Telegraph|date=27 Nov 2012}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph15Nov2013">{{cite news|last1=Bingham|first1=John|title=Roman Catholic Church says no new academies over cap on believers|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/10452994/Roman-Catholic-Church-says-no-new-academies-over-cap-on-believers.html|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=15 Nov 2013}}</ref><ref name="TES4Feb2014">{{cite news|last1=Barker|first1=Irena|title=Catholics won't invest in free schools and academies unless cap on believers is lifted|url=https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/catholics-wont-invest-free-schools-and-academies-unless-cap-believers|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=Times Educational Supplement|date=4 Feb 2014}}</ref><ref name="TheTablet2015">{{cite news|last1=Lamb|first1=Christopher|title=Bishops hope new Government will lift admissions cap on academies|url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/2083/0/bishops-hopeful-new-conservative-government-will-lift-admissions-cap-on-academies|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=The Tablet|date=19 May 2015}}</ref> In April 2014, the issue was aired in the House of Commons in a debate led by [[Damian Hinds|Damian Hinds MP]].<ref name="Hansard30April2014">{{cite web|title=House of Commons Catholic Schools (Admissions) Debate 30 April 2014|url=http://catholicunion.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Catholic-Schools-admission-debate-30-Apr-2014.pdf|publisher=Hansard|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref>
The Coalition Government was replaced by a Conservative Government in the [[2015 General Election]]. The Schools Minister with responsibility for Free Schools, [[John Nash, Baron Nash|Lord Nash]], told campaigners that there were no plans to review the 50% Rule.<ref name="LordNash2015">{{cite web|title=No plans to review 50% free schools admissions cap, says DfE|publisher=National Secular Society|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> However, the following year, [[Nick Timothy]], the newly appointed director of the [[New Schools Network]], responsible for encouraging and supporting the establishment of Free Schools, spoke out in favour of ending it.<ref name="NTimothyBBC2016">{{cite news|last1=Coughlan|first1=Sean|title=Call to end limit on religious free schools|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-35411525|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=BBC|date=28 January 2016}}</ref>
When [[Theresa May]] became Prime Minister in 2016, Nick Timothy became her Joint Chief of Staff,<ref name="GuardianNickTimothy2016">{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Rowena|title=May appoints former advisers as joint chiefs of staff|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/15/may-appoints-former-advisers-as-joint-chiefs-of-staff|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=The Guardian|date=15 July 2016}}</ref> and was credited as responsible when later the same year a national consultation by the Department for Education asked for people's views on removing the 50% Rule, to enable new faith academies to select up to 100% of pupils based on their faith.<ref name="dfeconsultation">{{cite web|title=Schools that work for everyone|url=https://consult.education.gov.uk/school-frameworks/schools-that-work-for-everyone/|website=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="PaulGoodmanSep2016">{{cite web|last1=Goodman|first1=Paul|title=The treatment of Catholic schools is a "burning injustice" – a wrong that May is now set to right|url=https://www.conservativehome.com/thetorydiary/2016/09/the-treatment-of-catholic-schools-is-a-burning-injustice-a-wrong-that-may-is-now-set-to-right.html|website=Conservativehome|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref> The move was opposed by individuals and groups campaigning for inclusive admissions, including the [[Accord Coalition]], [[Humanists UK]] and the [https://www.secularism.org.uk National Secular Society] as well as other commentators.<ref name="AccordNov2016">{{cite web|title=Civil society leaders urge Government to rethink removing 50% faith selection cap|url=http://accordcoalition.org.uk/2016/11/07/civil-society-leaders-urge-government-to-rethink-removing-50-faith-selection-cap/|publisher=Accord Coalition|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="IndependentJune2017">{{cite news|last1=Romain|first1=Jonathan|title=At a time when social cohesion is needed more than ever, the Tories' pledge to ghettoise religious schools is shocking|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/general-election-2017-faith-schools-religious-50-percent-cap-segregation-a7770856.html|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Independent|date=3 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph9Sep2016">{{cite news|last1=Cantle|first1=Ted|title=Religious selection in school admissions is utterly deleterious for integration|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2016/09/09/religious-selection-in-school-admissions-is-utterly-deleterious/|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=9 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="HUKConsultationResponse">{{cite web|title=Schools that work for everyone: response of the British Humanist Association|url=https://humanism.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016-12-12-FINAL-Schools-that-work-for-everyone-BHA-consultation-response.pdf|publisher=Humanists UK|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="CEEJan2017">{{cite web|last1=Croft|first1=James|title=Should we allow faith selection? Should the 50% cap be lifted from faith selective schools to allow their expansion?|url=http://www.cfee.org.uk/node/180|publisher=Centre for Education Economics|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="NSSJuly2017">{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Stephen|title=Intolerant religion mustn’t dictate England’s education policy|url=http://www.secularism.org.uk/opinion/2017/07/intolerant-religion-mustnt-dictate-englands-education-policy|website=National Secular Society|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> The results of the consultation were seen as a foregone conclusion by the Catholic Education Service, which wrote in its 2016 annual report: "After a CES coordinated campaign which put pressure on Government officials, parliamentarians and Downing Street special advisers, the Prime Minister announced the removal of the 50% cap on faith-based admission for new Free Schools. This announcement means that Catholic dioceses will be able to open new Catholic schools for the first time in six years."<ref name="CESAnnualReport2016">{{cite web|title=The 169th Annual Report of the Catholic Education Service (2016)|url=http://www.catholiceducation.org.uk/images/AnnualZReportZ2016ZFinal_2.pdf|publisher=Catholic Education Service|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>
However, in April 2017, before the results of the consultation were published, Theresa May called a [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|snap General Election]], with Nick Timothy as a senior advisor for her campaign.<ref name="ITVElection2017">{{cite news|title=Election 2017: Who are the key behind-the-scenes figures directing Tory and Labour campaigns?|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2017-04-19/election-2017-who-are-the-key-behind-the-scenes-figures-directing-tory-and-labour-campaigns/|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=ITV|date=19 April 2017}}</ref> Their Conservative manifesto included a pledge to "replace the unfair and ineffective inclusivity rules that prevent the establishment of new Roman Catholic schools."<ref name="ConManifesto2017">{{cite web|title=Forward, Together - Our Plan for a Stronger Britain and a Prosperous Future|url=https://s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/manifesto2017/Manifesto2017.pdf|publisher=The Conservative Party|accessdate=27 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170615162039/https://s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/manifesto2017/Manifesto2017.pdf|archivedate=15 June 2017|df=}}</ref>
When the election resulted in a [[Second May ministry|hung parliament]], Nick Timothy resigned,<ref name="NTimothyResigns">{{cite web|last1=Timothy|first1=Nick|title=Nick Timothy: Why I have resigned as the Prime Minister’s adviser|url=https://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2017/06/nick-timothy-why-i-have-resigned-as-the-prime-ministers-adviser.html|website=Conservative Home|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref> and the future of many of the manifesto policies was thrown into doubt.<ref name="OpenUniQueensSpeech2017">{{cite web|title=What does the Queen's Speech tell us about the next two years?|url=http://www.open.edu/openlearn/society-politics-law/politics/what-does-the-queens-speech-tell-us-about-the-next-two-years|publisher=Open University|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref> This resulted in speculation as to whether the 50% Rule would be repealed or not, and associated lobbying and campaigning on both sides of the debate.<ref name="TabletJuly2017">{{cite news|last1=Lamb|first1=Christopher|title=Theresa May repeats support for faith schools saying further details on admission policy will be published soon|url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/7504/0/theresa-may-repeats-support-for-faith-schools-saying-further-details-on-admission-policy-will-be-published-soon-|accessdate=27 August 2017|work=The Tablet|date=19 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="HumUkJuly2017">{{cite web|title=Government in rethink of fully segregated ‘faith’ schools proposal?|url=https://humanism.org.uk/2017/07/23/government-in-rethink-of-fully-segregated-faith-schools-proposal/|publisher=Humanists UK|accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="TimesSep1st2017">{{cite news|last1=Romain|first1=Jonathan|title=Don’t let religious apartheid infect our faith schools|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/don-t-let-religious-apartheid-infect-our-faith-schools-3pjrmtqkl|accessdate=4 September 2017|work=The Times|date=1 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="CopsonSchoolsWeekJun2017">{{cite web|last1=Copson|first1=Andrew|title=Will the Conservatives really remove the faith school 50% cap?|url=https://schoolsweek.co.uk/will-the-conservatives-really-remove-the-faith-school-50-cap/|publisher=Schools Week|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="JCJuly282017">{{cite news|last1=Rocker|first1=Simon|title=Debate continues over faith school entry limit|url=https://www.thejc.com/education/education-news/debate-continues-over-faith-school-entry-limit-1.442153|accessdate=21 October 2017|date=28 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="ReferralForUnlawfulPromotionTESNov2017">{{cite news|last1=Bloom|first1=Adi|title=Catholic schools are 'unlawfully' promoting political action, humanists say|url=https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/catholic-schools-are-unlawfully-promoting-political-action-humanists|accessdate=7 December 2017|work=Times Educational Supplement|date=6 December 2017}}</ref> Nevertheless, eight months after the consultation report was expected to be published, the Government said it was "still considering how best to progress the policy proposals ... in light of the responses to the consultation."<ref name="SchoolsWeek3Nov2017">{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Freddie|title=DfE last changed grammar school response in June — but still refuses to publish|url=https://schoolsweek.co.uk/dfe-still-refusing-to-publish-grammar-school-consultation-response/|accessdate=3 November 2017|work=Schools Week|date=3 Nov 2017}}</ref>
In January 2018, a Cabinet reshuffle resulted in the incumbent Education Secretary, [[Justine Greening]], being replaced by [[Damian Hinds]], whose record of supporting the Catholic Education Service's position on the 50% Rule fuelled speculation that he planned to implement the Government's manifesto pledge to remove it.<ref name="DamianHindsJan2018">{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Freddie|title=Damian Hinds: The new sheriff in town|url=https://schoolsweek.co.uk/damian-hinds-the-new-sheriff-in-town/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Schools Week|date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="DamianHindsCatholicHerald">{{cite news|last1=Hallett|first1=Nick|title=Church school supporter is new Education Secretary|url=http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2018/01/09/church-school-supporter-is-new-education-secretary/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=The Catholic Herald|date=9 January 2018}}</ref> The following month, he confirmed that was his intention.<ref name="DHindsFeb2018">{{cite news|last1=Hepburn|first1=Henry|title=Grammar school expansion and faith school reforms: Damian Hinds sets out his stall|url=https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-news/grammar-school-expansion-and-faith-school-reforms-damian-hinds-sets|accessdate=19 February 2018|work=Times Educational Supplement|date=18 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="Independent22Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Busby|first1=Eleanor|title=Parliamentary inquiry demanded over minister's plans to allow new faith schools to take fewer pupils from different backgrounds|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/faith-schools-religions-education-select-committee-parliamentary-inquiry-damian-hinds-selection-free-a8222021.html|accessdate=26 February 2018|work=Independent|date=22 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="SchoolsWeek23Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Freddie|title=Catholics pray for free schools miracle|url=https://schoolsweek.co.uk/catholics-pray-for-free-schools-miracle/|accessdate=26 February 2018|work=Schools Week|date=23 February 2018}}</ref> However, in May 2018 it was announced that the 50% cap would remain in place. Instead the Government said it would provide financial support for local authorities that want to work with faith groups to create new [[Voluntary aided school|voluntary aided]] schools.<ref name="DfeDecision11May2018">{{cite web|title=Drive to create more good school places for families|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/drive-to-create-more-good-school-places-for-families|website=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="HUKDecisionMay2018">{{cite web|title=Government to offer funds for new fully selective religious schools out of free schools pot|url=https://humanism.org.uk/2018/05/11/government-to-offer-funds-for-new-fully-selective-religious-schools-out-of-free-schools-pot/|publisher=Humanists UK|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="TabletMay2018">{{cite news|last1=Gledhill|first1=Ruth|title=Damian Hinds says schools faith cap will stay|url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/9054/damian-hinds-says-schools-faith-cap-will-stay|accessdate=11 May 2018|work=The Tablet|date=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="JCDecisionMay2018">{{cite news|last1=Weinstein|first1=Jessica|title=Faith schools’ admissions cap to stay, Education Secretary Damian Hinds confirms|url=https://www.thejc.com/education/education-news/faith-schools-admissions-cap-to-stay-education-secretary-damian-hinds-confirms-1.463986|accessdate=11 May 2018|work=The Jewish Chronicle|date=11 May 2018}}</ref>
== Application and Interpretation == ===Catholic Free Schools=== The Catholic Education Service refused to support the establishment of new faith academies under the 50% Rule because they interpreted it as forcing schools "to turn pupils away because they were Catholics while admitting others because they were not".<ref name="Telegraph27Nov2012" /> They said that this would be against Canon Law,<ref name="Tablet28Aug2017">{{cite news|last1=Gamble|first1=Rose|title=Church welcomes abolition of cap on faith-school admissions|url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/6121/0/church-welcomes-abolition-of-cap-on-faith-school-admissions|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Tablet}}</ref> although campaigners for inclusive admissions argued that their claim was "disingenuous and politically motivated".<ref name="HumanistsUKBriefingOn50pcCap">{{cite web|title=Religious lobbying around the 50% cap on religious selectio|url=https://humanism.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016-11-17-BHA-briefing-Religious-lobbying-on-50-per-cent-cap.pdf|publisher=Humanist UK|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> The chairperson of the CES has said: “The Church of England runs schools for the wider community ..... Ours are different. They are for the Catholic community.”<ref name="ArchbishLiverpoolGuardian">{{cite news|last1=Wilby|first1=Peter|title=Catholic archbishop: grammars and free schools now on the hymn sheet|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/may/02/catholic-grammars-free-schools-malcolm-mcmahon-archbishop-liverpool|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=The Guardian|date=2 May 2017}}</ref>
One Catholic Free School ''was'' established, [[St Michael's Secondary School|St Michael's in Camborne]], as a conversion from the private sector. It originally received "one off" approval from church officials,<ref name="FreebutFettered2013">{{cite news|last1=Sutcliffe|first1=Jeremy|title=Free but Fettered|url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/features/2/677/free-but-fettered|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=The Tablet|date=26 October 2013}}</ref> but this was later withdrawn and, after it failed to thrive, the school was eventually absorbed into a community academy.<ref name="StMichaelsGuardianMay2015">{{cite news|last1=Adams|first1=Richard|title=Fate of Cornwall's first free school hangs in balance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2015/may/01/fate-of-cornwalls-first-free-school-hangs-in-balance|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=The Guardian|date=1 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="StMichaelsBBCMay2015">{{cite news|title=Camborne's £4.5m St Michael's free school 'not viable'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cornwall-32763335|accessdate=29 August 2017|date=16 May 2015}}</ref> While it was operating as a Catholic free school it was found to misinterpret the 50% Rule, because its oversubscription criteria prioritised 50% of places for "non-Catholics" rather than allocating them "without reference to faith". This was judged to be a breach of the Admissions Code,<ref name="ADA2638">{{cite web|title=Determination ADA2638|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/333020/ADA2638_St_Michaels_Catholic_Secondary.pdf|publisher=Office of the Schools Adjudicator|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> a judgement which confirmed that places allocated "without reference to faith" should be just as accessible to Catholics (or other faith groups) as to those without a faith affiliation.
Another Free School, [[Trinity Academy, Brixton|Trinity Academy]] in Brixton, opened without a formal Catholic designation (for which it would have needed the support of the church authorities),<ref name="NSNFaithSchoolGuidance">{{cite web|title=Faith Free Schools Application Guidance|url=https://www.newschoolsnetwork.org/sites/default/files/Faith%20free%20schools.docx.pdf|website=New Schools Network|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref> but with a Catholic ethos, and oversubscription criteria that allocated 100% of places without reference to faith.<ref name="TrinityBrixton">{{cite web|title=About Trinity|url=http://www.trinityacademylondon.org/headteachers-welcome|website=Trinity Academy|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref> The school's founder has spoken out against the Catholic Education Service's position on the 50% rule, describing it as "stubborn" and a missed opportunity for evangelism.<ref name="SpectatorBlog28Sept2017">{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Damian|title=The knives are out for Christian faith schools|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/07/the-knives-are-out-for-christian-faith-schools/|website=The Spectator|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref>
When [[St Richard Reynolds Catholic College|St Richard Reynolds Catholic High School and Primary School]] were established in the London Borough of Richmond Upon Thames in 2013, campaign groups accused the local authority of helping the Catholic church to avoid the 50% Rule, by providing financial and political support for them to be set up as [[Voluntary aided school|Voluntary Aided schools]] rather than Free Schools, and setting a legal precedent for interpretation of [[Education Act 2011|2011 Education Act]].<ref name="DWolfeDec2012">{{cite web|last1=Wolfe|first1=David|title=No longer a presumption that new schools will be academies?|url=http://davidwolfe.org.uk/wordpress/archives/1390|website=A Can of Worms|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="RTTOct2012">{{cite news|last1=Bishop|first1=Rachel|title=New Twickenham Catholic school named, despite High Court battle|url=http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/9980383.New_Catholic_school_named__despite_High_Court_battle/|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=Richmond and Twickenham Times|date=13 October 2012}}</ref> The Education Secretary suggested that the school should "voluntarily" adhere to the 50% rule.<ref name="GoveGuardian30Mar2012"/> In the end, the diocesan authorities did provide 10 open places in the primary school,<ref name="LBRuTConsultation2012">{{cite web|title=Consultation with Richmond upon Thames residents on use of the Clifden Road site, Twickenham|url=https://cabnet.richmond.gov.uk/documents/s33088/Cabinet%2024%20May%20re%20Clifden%20Road%20Appendix%201.pdf|publisher=London Borough of Richmond upon Thames|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref> however, like St. Michaels in Camborne, they were also required by the Schools' Adjudicator to modify the wording of their policy to ensure that Catholic children could access the open places.<ref name="AdjudicatorADA3114">{{cite web|title=Decision: St Richard Reynolds Catholic College|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/st-richard-reynolds-catholic-college|publisher=Office of the Schools' Adjudicator|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref>
===Church of England Free Schools=== The Church of England (CE) is establishing large numbers of new schools under the Free School programme.<ref name="Guardian10July2016">{{cite news|last1=Sherwood|first1=Harriet|title=Church of England is bidding to open scores of free schools|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/jul/10/church-of-england-bidding-open-free-schools|accessdate=28 August 2017|date=10 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="FreeSchoolsWithFaithDes">{{cite web|title=List of free schools in England which are formally designated as faith schools|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/_List_of_free_schools_in_England_which_are_formally_designated_as_faith_schools|website=Wikipedia|accessdate=25 October 2017}}</ref> The [[Justin Welby|Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby]], has said that the Church of England is moving away from selecting pupils based on religion.<ref name="JustinWelby2013">{{cite news|last1=Philipson|first1=Alice|title=Church 'moving away' from selecting school pupils based on religion|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/10448412/Church-moving-away-from-selecting-school-pupils-based-on-religion.html|accessdate=28 August 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=14 November 2013}}</ref> Responding to the proposal to remove the 50% Rule, their Chief Education Officer stated that “Our schools are not faith schools for the faithful, they are church schools for the community.”<ref name="CofEConsultationResponse">{{cite web|title=Church of England responds to Government education proposals|url=https://www.churchofengland.org/media-centre/news/2016/09/church-of-england-responds-to-government-education-proposals.aspx|publisher=Church of England|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> However, campaign groups have said that the admissions authorities for CE schools frequently do not follow this advice.<ref name="SchoolsWeekOnAccordReportNov2017">{{cite news|last1=Allen-Kinross|first1=Pippa|title=Church schools accused of ‘discriminatory’ admissions|url=https://schoolsweek.co.uk/church-schools-accused-of-discriminatory-admissions/|accessdate=21 November 2017|work=Schools Week|date=21 November 2017}}</ref>
Some Church of England free schools go beyond what is required by the 50% Rule and have oversubscription criteria which allocate 100% of places without reference to faith, in line with many of their established [[Voluntary controlled school|Voluntary Controlled schools]].<ref name="StMarysHampton">{{cite web|title=St Mary's Hampton CE Primary School|url=http://www.stmaryshamptonschool.org.uk/|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="WynyardPrimary">{{cite web|title=Wynyard Church of England Primary School|url=http://wynyardprimary.org.uk/|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="WalthamstowAdm">{{cite web|title=Admissions|url=http://www.walthamstowprimaryacademy.org.uk/Information/Admissions|website=Walthamstow Primary Academy|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
One school's interpretation of the 50% Rule was judged to be unreasonable, because it designated Church of England primary schools, which themselves had faith-based admissions criteria, as feeder schools for the 50% of places that were being allocated without reference to faith.<ref name="ADA3209">{{cite web|title=Determination ADA3209|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/becket-keys-church-of-england-school|publisher=Office of the Schools Adjudicator|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
Following the Government's consultation on removal of the 50% Rule, one proposed CE Free School apparently published plans for oversubscription criteria that selected only 25% of places without reference to faith, prompting criticism that people were "jumping the gun" in assuming the change would go ahead. However, the school later said the policy description on their website had been incorrect.<ref name="SchoolsWeek5April2017">{{cite news|last1=Staufenberg|first1=Jess|title=Church of England school backs down on proposal for 75% faith places at free school|url=http://schoolsweek.co.uk/church-of-england-school-backs-down-on-proposal-for-75-faith-places-at-free-school/|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=Schools Week|date=5 April 2017}}</ref>
===Other Faith Free Schools=== The Free School programme has resulted in the establishment of many new schools with several faith designations, including other Christian denominations, Jewish, Hindu, Sikh and Muslim,<ref name="FreeSchoolsWithFaithDes"/> all of which are subject to the 50% Rule.
Some senior members of the Jewish community have publicly supported the removal of the 50% Rule.<ref name="jc9Sep2016">{{cite news|title=Theresa May to remove cap on faith-school admissions|url=https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/theresa-may-to-remove-cap-on-faith-school-admissions-1.52973|accessdate=30 August 2017|work=Jewish Chronicle|date=9 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="JNOnline9Sep2016">{{cite news|title=Community welcomes plans to relax admission rules for Jewish schools|url=http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/community-welcomes-plans-to-relax-admission-rules-for-jewish-schools/|accessdate=30 August 2017|work=Jewish News Online|date=9 September 2016}}</ref>
== Impact == The Government's 2016 consultation document "Schools that Work for Everyone", which was proposing removal of the 50% Rule, said that "in open free schools designated for minority faiths in the English school system (Islam, Judaism, Sikhism and Hinduism) the intake has been predominantly of pupils from similar ethnic backgrounds". They contrasted this with Voluntary Aided Catholic schools which they said have higher levels of diversity on average, despite not being subject to the 50% Rule.<ref name="dfeconsultation"/>
The same document said "“Other Christian” free schools have nearly a fifth of pupils of Asian origin and nearly a tenth from black ethnic families, with just 55% of White ethnic origin".
In response to the consultation, a campaign group in favour of retaining the 50% Rule published analysis indicating that schools subject to the rule are more ethnically diverse than those that aren't, concluding that "if the 50% cap was rolled out across all state-funded secondary schools then .. whilst there would be little difference for the minority faith schools, tens or even hundreds of thousands of non-white pupils would gain access to Christian schools when they haven’t had access before."<ref name="HUKFreeSchoolDiversityPaper">{{cite web|title=Ethnic diversity in religious Free Schools|url=https://humanism.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016-09-15-FINAL-Ethnic-diversity-in-religious-Free-Schools.pdf|website=Humanist UK|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
